{"uri": "8252341040", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "11:23:49", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T11:23:49Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T11:22:42Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7607843279838562, "url": "https://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/entertainment/english/music/news/megan-thee-stallion-supports-kamala-harris-for-first-black-female-president/articleshow/112168035.cms", "title": "Megan Thee Stallion supports Kamala Harris for 'first Black female president' | - Times of India", "body": "U.S. Vice President Kamala Harris joined rappers Megan Thee Stallion and Quavo at a spirited Atlanta rally that highlighted the new energy she has brought to November's election.\n\nIn a vibrant show of support for the Vice President's presidential campaign, Megan Thee Stallion electrified a crowd of 10,000 last night at a rally in Atlanta, Georgia. The Texas rapper declared to the enthusiastic audience that the United States is \"about to make history with the first Black female president\".\n\nThe Grammy-winning artist performed a dynamic set of four songs, including hits \"Girls in the Hood,\" \"Mamushi,\" \"Body,\" and \"Savage.\" As she introduced her track \"Body,\" Megan Thee Stallion addressed the crowd, saying, \"Now I know my ladies in the crowd love their bodies - and if you want to keep loving your body, you know who to vote for.\"\n\nIn her first trip to Georgia as a presidential candidate on Tuesday, Harris pledged Democrats will win a state the party had written off, and taunted Republican Donald Trump for backing out of a debate with her.\n\nThe momentum in this race is shifting, and \"Donald Trump is feeling it,\" Harris said, as the crowd of about 10,000 cheered and shouted her nascent campaign slogan \"We are not going back.\"\n\nWith less than 100 days left in one of the least predictable campaign seasons in recent history, Democrats are redrawing their map to victory, hoping the prospect of the first Black and Asian woman president can motivate Democrats to the polls.\n\nHarris' election campaign, hastily put together after President Joe Biden ended his re-election bid on July 22, has raised $200 million, and signed up 170,000 new volunteers.\n\nIn Atlanta, Harris embraced some Biden policy priorities, promising, \"On Day One I will take on price gouging and bring down costs.\" She said she would ban more hidden banking fees, take on corporate landlords and \"cap unfair rent increases\".\n\nShe also addressed immigration on the southern border, a top issue for Republican voters after the arrests of migrants crossing illegally reached a high during the Biden administration. Harris' role in trying to tamp down migration has drawn Republican criticism.\n\nTrump has been \"talking a big game about securing the border,\" but he does not walk the walk, Harris said. Trump pushed Republicans to tank a bill that would have funded more border security measures, she added, referring to a bill that failed in February.\n\nMegan Thee Stallion, whose album \"Megan\" recently launched at No. 1 on Billboard's Top R&B/Hip-Hop albums chart, performed before Harris spoke while wearing a blue pantsuit and tie, the color associated with Harris' Democratic Party. \"Lets get this done hotties. Hotties for Harris,\" she told the crowd.\n\nGEORGIA IN PLAY?\n\nGeorgia Senator Jon Ossoff, a Democrat, said on MSNBC over the weekend that Harris' entry into the race \"has put Georgia in play\" for Democrats and predicted she will win.\n\nSwing states like Georgia, which Democrats barely won in 2020, are fiercely contested because they can lean either to Republicans or Democrats and play a decisive role in presidential elections.\n\nFiveThirtyEight, the poll aggregation site, shows Republican Donald Trump leading Harris by between one and five percentage points in surveys taken after Harris became the likely Democratic candidate.\n\nSince Biden ended his reelection bid for the Nov. 5 vote against Trump, Harris has significantly outperformed him in recent polling among young people, Black voters and Hispanic voters.\n\nAfter Harris's speech, she appeared on a Zoom call with supporters, telling them \"this is a sprint\" and asking them to volunteer. Her campaign's battleground director Dan Kanninen said the team was looking at the \"Blue wall\" states of Pennsylvania, Wisconsin and Michigan to win the election, but was also hopeful about the \"Sun Belt.\"\n\nA New York Times/Siena College national poll published on Thursday found Harris has narrowed a sizable Trump lead, while Trump had a two percentage point lead in a Wall Street Journal poll published on Friday. A Reuters/Ipsos poll published on Tuesday showed Harris with a one point lead over Trump, down from two points in a July 23 poll.\n\nBiden's campaign saw a narrowing path to victory with the \"Sun Belt states,\" including Georgia, Arizona and Nevada, as unlikely wins. Georgia backed Biden by 0.2 percentage points, just under 12,000 votes in 2020, and Trump by around 5 percentage points in 2016.\n\nAndy Beshear, the twice-elected Democratic governor of deep-red Kentucky, visited Georgia over the weekend to campaign for Harris in the Republican stronghold of Forsyth County.\n\nThe Harris campaign is vetting him along with Senator Mark Kelly of Arizona, Governor Josh Shapiro of Pennsylvania and Governor Tim Walz of Minnesota as possible vice presidential candidates. A decision is expected by Aug. 7.\n\nHarris is leaning into her resume as a former district attorney and California attorney general, seeking to draw a contrast with Trump who is the first former president to be convicted of felony crimes.\n\nTrump and 14 co-defendants are accused of racketeering and other charges for their role in attempting to overturn Biden's narrow win in Georgia.", {"uri": "8251668202", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "03:32:28", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T03:32:28Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T03:31:43Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7529411911964417, "url": "https://www.firstpost.com/world/say-it-to-my-face-kamala-harris-takes-direct-aim-at-trump-at-boisterous-georgia-rally-13798987.html", "title": "'Say it to my face': Kamala Harris takes direct aim at Trump at boisterous Georgia rally", "body": "Vice President Kamala Harris speaks during a campaign rally, Tuesday, July 30, 2024, in Atlanta. AP\n\nVice President Kamala Harris told a cheering, boisterous, packed Atlanta arena on Tuesday that the next 98 days would be a fight, but they'd win come November, as she taunted Donald Trump for wavering on whether he'd show up for their upcoming debate.\n\n\"The momentum in this race is shifting,\" the likely nominee said. \"And there are signs Donald Trump is feeling it.\"\n\nLittle more than a week ago, Georgia appeared to be slipping out of the Democrats' reach: President Joe Biden's campaign pledged to concentrate more on holding the Midwestern \"blue wall\" states and indicated they might be willing to forsake \"Sun Belt\" battlegrounds. But now that Biden has bowed out of the race and Harris is the likely nominee, Democrats are expressing new hopes of an expanded electoral map.\n\nIn the state that delivered Biden his narrowest victory margin in 2020, Harris pulled off what has been a signature Trump event: A big, loud rally full of supporters cheering her name, as she mocked her rival and his running mate JD Vance as \"just plain weird,\" and derided their policies as backward, outdated and dangerous.\n\nTrump earlier said he'd debate Harris, but is now questioning the value of a meetup and saying he \"probably\" will debate her, but he \"can also make a case for not doing it.\"\n\nHarris seized on it. \"So he won't debate me, but he and his running mate have a lot to say about me,\" she said. \"And by the way, don't you find some of their stuff to just be plain weird.\"\n\n\"Well Donald,\" she said, addressing him head-on. \"I do hope you'll reconsider. Meet me on the debate stage &mldr; because as the saying goes, if you've got something to say, say it to my face.\" Trump has suggested the Sept. 10 debate on ABC News should be moved to a different network, calling ABC \"fake news.\"\n\nHarris hasn't yet formally seized the Democrat nomination, though she is the only person who met the qualifications to vie for it, the Democratic National Committee announced Tuesday, and will all-but-certainly clinch it come Monday when the party concludes a virtual roll call vote. Her pick of a running mate is also expected by early next week when Harris plans to begin a seven-stop tour of battleground states to hold rallies alongside her vice presidential nominee.\n\nOn Tuesday, the roughly 8,000-capacity basketball arena at Georgia State University was filled to its rafters with voters waving signs, dancing to the Harris campaign soundtrack and a performance by Megan Thee Stallion. Such an atmosphere would not have been possible just 10 days ago, with the party reeling over whether the 81-year-old Biden would remain in the race after a dismal performance magnified concerns about his age and abilities and ultimately ended his campaign.\n\n\"This is like Barack Obama 2008 on steroids for me,\" said Mildred Hobson Doss, a 59-year-old who came downtown from suburban Lilburn. \"I would have voted for President Biden again. But we are ready.\"\n\nHarris' campaign argues her appeal to young people, working-age women and non-white voters has scrambled the dynamics in Georgia and other states that are demographically similar, from North Carolina to Nevada and Arizona.\n\nIn a strategy memo released after the president left the race, Harris campaign chair Jen O'Malley Dillon, who held the same role for Biden, reaffirmed the importance of winning Michigan, Wisconsin and Pennsylvania, a trio of industrial states that have formed the traditional Democratic blue wall.\n\nBut she also argued that the vice president's place atop the ticket \"opens up additional persuadable voters\" and described them as \"disproportionately Black, Latino and under 30\" in places like Georgia.\n\n\"The energy is infectious,\" said Georgia Democratic Chairwoman Nikema Williams, a congresswoman from Atlanta. \"My phone has been blowing up. People want to be part of this movement.\"\n\nHarris began Tuesday with her days as a prosecutor -- setting up the contrast between the law and Trump's many legal problems and misdeeds. But she also aggressively defended the Biden administration's record and said she would work to pass voting rights legislation and restore abortion rights stripped by the fall of Roe v. Wade.\n\n\"America has tried these failed policies before. And we are not going back. We're not going back,\" Harris said, shaking her head no as the crowd cheered \"we're not going back.\"\n\nRepublicans, who still control Georgia's state government, counter that Biden's lagging popularity and concern over higher consumer prices and immigration will transfer to Harris in the historically conservative state.\n\nBut they concede that the landscape suddenly looks much closer to 2020 - when Biden won by about 0.25 percentage points -- than when Trump was riding high after the Republican National Convention and surviving an assassination attempt.\n\n\"Trump was going to win Georgia. It was over,\" said Republican consultant Brian Robinson. \"The Democrats have a chance here for a reset.\"\n\nAnd Trump is not taking chances. Earlier Tuesday, the former president announced that he would come to Atlanta on Saturday for a rally in the same Georgia State arena.\n\nRobinson said Harris still has plenty of liabilities, including the progressive positions she took in her failed 2020 primary campaign and her various rhetorical stumbles. But he said Harris so far in this campaign has been \"in command,\" and if that continues, \"we have a new ballgame and she will be competitive in Georgia.\"\n\nTrump campaign spokesperson Karoline Leavitt dismissed Harris as \"just as weak, failed and incompetent as Joe Biden\" and said the vice president would have to explain her support of Biden administration policies that \"hurt working families in Georgia over the past four years.\"\n\nThe campaign and Georgia Democratic officials have 24 offices across the state, including two added last weekend in metro Atlanta. Trump and the Republican National Committee opened their first Georgia offices only recently.\n\nIn a call with supporters after her speech, Harris thanked them for their work and noted early voting starts in some states in just 38 days.\n\n\"This is a sprint,\" she said. \"And we know what we need to do to cross the finish line.\"\n\nThe fast-growing, diversifying Atlanta suburbs and exurbs offer the most opportunity for swings, especially from GOP-leaning moderates disenchanted with Trump.\n\nFor Harris, that means depending on voters as varied as Michael Sleister, a white suburbanite, and Allen Smith, a Black man who lives not far from downtown Atlanta.\n\nSleister, who considers himself an independent, has lived in Forsyth County for 35 years. \"I've voted Republican many times in my life,\" he said, but not since the GOP took a rightward turn during President Barack Obama's administration.\n\n\"Now I see the Republican Party as representing a direct threat to my grandchildren,\" he said, adding that he sees Trump \"as just a horrible person.\"\n\nSmith is a 41-year-old Atlanta native who has become a first-time campaign volunteer since Harris became the likely nominee.\n\n\"I was driving when I heard the news about President Biden endorsing her, and I started pounding my fist -- I decided right then I would do whatever I could to help her get elected,\" Smith said.", "source": {"uri": "firstpost.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Firstpost"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kamala_Harris", "type": {"uri": "8252308346", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "11:04:44", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T11:04:44Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T11:03:59Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7411764860153198, "url": "https://www.sunjournal.com/2024/07/30/at-boisterous-georgia-rally-harris-says-she-will-show-trump-what-real-leadership-looks-like/", "title": "At Georgia rally, Harris dares Trump to 'say it to my face' and debate her", "body": "Vice President Kamala Harris arrives at a campaign rally on Tuesday in Atlanta. The roughly 8,000-capacity basketball arena at Georgia State University was filled to its rafters. John Bazemore/Associated Press\n\nATLANTA -- Vice President Kamala Harris told a cheering, boisterous, packed Atlanta arena on Tuesday that the next 98 days would be a fight, but they'd win come November, as she taunted Donald Trump for wavering on whether he'd show up for their upcoming debate.\n\n\"The momentum in this race is shifting,\" the likely nominee said. \"And there are signs Donald Trump is feeling it.\"\n\nLittle more than a week ago, Georgia appeared to be slipping out of the Democrats' reach: President Biden's campaign pledged to concentrate more on holding the Midwestern \"blue wall\" states and indicated they might be willing to forsake \"Sun Belt\" battlegrounds. But now that Biden has bowed out of the race and Harris is the likely nominee, Democrats are expressing new hopes of an expanded electoral map.\n\nIn the state that delivered Biden his narrowest victory margin in 2020, Harris pulled off what has been a signature Trump event: A big, loud rally full of supporters cheering her name, as she mocked her rival and his running mate JD Vance as \"just plain weird,\" and derided their policies as backward, outdated and dangerous.\n\nTrump earlier said he'd debate Harris, but is now questioning the value of a meetup and saying he \"probably\" will debate her, but he \"can also make a case for not doing it.\"\n\nHarris seized on it. \"So he won't debate me, but he and his running mate have a lot to say about me,\" she said. \"And by the way, don't you find some of their stuff to just be plain weird.\"\n\nAdvertisement\n\n\"Well Donald,\" she said, addressing him head-on. \"I do hope you'll reconsider. Meet me on the debate stage ... because as the saying goes, if you've got something to say, say it to my face.\" Trump has suggested the Sept. 10 debate on ABC News should be moved to a different network, calling ABC \"fake news.\"\n\nHarris hasn't yet formally seized the Democrat nomination, though she is the only person who met the qualifications to vie for it, the Democratic National Committee announced Tuesday, and will all-but-certainly clinch it come Monday when the party concludes a virtual roll call vote. Her pick of a running mate is also expected by early next week when Harris plans to begin a seven-stop tour of battleground states to hold rallies alongside her vice presidential nominee.\n\nOn Tuesday, the roughly 8,000-capacity basketball arena at Georgia State University was filled to its rafters with voters waving signs, dancing to the Harris campaign soundtrack and a performance by Megan Thee Stallion. Such an atmosphere would not have been possible just 10 days ago, with the party reeling over whether the 81-year-old Biden would remain in the race after a dismal performance magnified concerns about his age and abilities and ultimately ended his campaign.\n\n\"This is like Barack Obama 2008 on steroids for me,\" said Mildred Hobson Doss, a 59-year-old who came downtown from suburban Lilburn. \"I would have voted for President Biden again. But we are ready.\"\n\nHarris' campaign argues her appeal to young people, working-age women and non-white voters has scrambled the dynamics in Georgia and other states that are demographically similar, from North Carolina to Nevada and Arizona.\n\nIn a strategy memo released after the president left the race, Harris campaign chair Jen O'Malley Dillon, who held the same role for Biden, reaffirmed the importance of winning Michigan, Wisconsin and Pennsylvania, a trio of industrial states that have formed the traditional Democratic blue wall.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nBut she also argued that the vice president's place atop the ticket \"opens up additional persuadable voters\" and described them as \"disproportionately Black, Latino and under 30\" in places like Georgia.\n\n\"The energy is infectious,\" said Georgia Democratic Chairwoman Nikema Williams, a congresswoman from Atlanta. \"My phone has been blowing up. People want to be part of this movement.\"\n\nHarris began Tuesday with her days as a prosecutor - setting up the contrast between the law and Trump's many legal problems and misdeeds. But she also aggressively defended the Biden administration's record and said she would work to pass voting rights legislation and restore abortion rights stripped by the fall of Roe v. Wade.\n\n\"America has tried these failed policies before. And we are not going back. We're not going back,\" Harris said, shaking her head no as the crowd cheered \"we're not going back.\"\n\nRepublicans, who still control Georgia's state government, counter that Biden's lagging popularity and concern over higher consumer prices and immigration will transfer to Harris in the historically conservative state.\n\nBut they concede that the landscape suddenly looks much closer to 2020 - when Biden won by about 0.25 percentage points - than when Trump was riding high after the Republican National Convention and surviving an assassination attempt.\n\nAdvertisement\n\n\"Trump was going to win Georgia. It was over,\" said Republican consultant Brian Robinson. \"The Democrats have a chance here for a reset.\"\n\nAnd Trump is not taking chances. Earlier Tuesday, the former president announced that he would come to Atlanta on Saturday for a rally in the same Georgia State arena.\n\nRobinson said Harris still has plenty of liabilities, including the progressive positions she took in her failed 2020 primary campaign and her various rhetorical stumbles. But he said Harris so far in this campaign has been \"in command,\" and if that continues, \"we have a new ballgame and she will be competitive in Georgia.\"\n\nTrump campaign spokesperson Karoline Leavitt dismissed Harris as \"just as weak, failed and incompetent as Joe Biden\" and said the vice president would have to explain her support of Biden administration policies that \"hurt working families in Georgia over the past four years.\"\n\nThe campaign and Georgia Democratic officials have 24 offices across the state, including two added last weekend in metro Atlanta. Trump and the Republican National Committee opened their first Georgia offices only recently.\n\nIn a call with supporters after her speech, Harris thanked them for their work and noted early voting starts in some states in just 38 days.\n\nAdvertisement\n\n\"This is a sprint,\" she said. \"And we know what we need to do to cross the finish line.\"\n\nThe fast-growing, diversifying Atlanta suburbs and exurbs offer the most opportunity for swings, especially from GOP-leaning moderates disenchanted with Trump.\n\nFor Harris, that means depending on voters as varied as Michael Sleister, a white suburbanite, and Allen Smith, a Black man who lives not far from downtown Atlanta.\n\nSleister, who considers himself an independent, has lived in Forsyth County for 35 years. \"I've voted Republican many times in my life,\" he said, but not since the GOP took a rightward turn during President Barack Obama's administration.\n\n\"Now I see the Republican Party as representing a direct threat to my grandchildren,\" he said, adding that he sees Trump \"as just a horrible person.\"\n\nSmith is a 41-year-old Atlanta native who has become a first-time campaign volunteer since Harris became the likely nominee.\n\n\"I was driving when I heard the news about President Biden endorsing her, and I started pounding my fist - I decided right then I would do whatever I could to help her get elected,\" Smith said.\n\nCopy the Story Link\n\nSend questions/comments to the editors.\n\nfiled under: election 2024, kamala harris Related Stories Latest Articles", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "2024-07-438948674", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "02:48:43", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T02:48:43Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T02:38:35Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7411764860153198, "url": "https://www.wsav.com/news/at-boisterous-georgia-rally-harris-dares-trump-to-say-it-to-my-face-and-show-up-for-their-debate/", "title": "Harris dares Trump to 'say it to my face'", "body": "by: WILL WEISSERT, BILL BARROW and COLLEEN LONG Associated Press\n\nATLANTA (AP) -- Vice President Kamala Harris told a cheering, boisterous, packed Atlanta arena on Tuesday that the next 98 days would be a fight, but they'd win come November, as she taunted Donald Trump for wavering on whether he'd show up for their upcoming debate.\n\n\"The momentum in this race is shifting,\" the likely nominee said. \"And there are signs Donald Trump is feeling it.\"\n\nLittle more than a week ago, Georgia appeared to be slipping out of the Democrats' reach: President Joe Biden's campaign pledged to concentrate more on holding the Midwestern \"blue wall\" states and indicated they might be willing to forsake \"Sun Belt\" battlegrounds. But now that Biden has bowed out of the race and Harris is the likely nominee, Democrats are expressing new hopes of an expanded electoral map.\n\nIn the state that delivered Biden his narrowest victory margin in 2020, Harris pulled off what has been a signature Trump event: A big, loud rally full of supporters cheering her name, as she mocked her rival and his running mate JD Vance as \"just plain weird,\" and derided their policies as backward, outdated and dangerous.\n\nTrump earlier said he'd debate Harris, but is now questioning the value of a meetup and saying he \"probably\" will debate her, but he \"can also make a case for not doing it.\"\n\nHarris seized on it. \"So he won't debate me, but he and his running mate have a lot to say about me,\" she said. \"And by the way, don't you find some of their stuff to just be plain weird.\"\n\n\"Well Donald,\" she said, addressing him head-on. \"I do hope you'll reconsider. Meet me on the debate stage ... because as the saying goes, if you've got something to say, say it to my face.\" Trump has suggested the Sept. 10 debate on ABC News should be moved to a different network, calling ABC \"fake news.\"\n\nHarris hasn't yet formally seized the Democrat nomination, though she is the only person who met the qualifications to vie for it, the Democratic National Committee announced Tuesday, and will all-but-certainly clinch it come Monday when the party concludes a virtual roll call vote. Her pick of a running mate is also expected by early next week when Harris plans to begin a seven-stop tour of battleground states to hold rallies alongside her vice presidential nominee.\n\nOn Tuesday, the roughly 8,000-capacity basketball arena at Georgia State University was filled to its rafters with voters waving signs, dancing to the Harris campaign soundtrack and a performance by Megan Thee Stallion. Such an atmosphere would not have been possible just 10 days ago, with the party reeling over whether the 81-year-old Biden would remain in the race after a dismal performance magnified concerns about his age and abilities and ultimately ended his campaign.\n\n\"This is like Barack Obama 2008 on steroids for me,\" said Mildred Hobson Doss, a 59-year-old who came downtown from suburban Lilburn. \"I would have voted for President Biden again. But we are ready.\"\n\nHarris' campaign argues her appeal to young people, working-age women and non-white voters has scrambled the dynamics in Georgia and other states that are demographically similar, from North Carolina to Nevada and Arizona.\n\nIn a strategy memo released after the president left the race, Harris campaign chair Jen O'Malley Dillon, who held the same role for Biden, reaffirmed the importance of winning Michigan, Wisconsin and Pennsylvania, a trio of industrial states that have formed the traditional Democratic blue wall.\n\nBut she also argued that the vice president's place atop the ticket \"opens up additional persuadable voters\" and described them as \"disproportionately Black, Latino and under 30\" in places like Georgia.\n\n\"The energy is infectious,\" said Georgia Democratic Chairwoman Nikema Williams, a congresswoman from Atlanta. \"My phone has been blowing up. People want to be part of this movement.\"\n\nHarris began Tuesday with her days as a prosecutor -- setting up the contrast between the law and Trump's many legal problems and misdeeds. But she also aggressively defended the Biden administration's record and said she would work to pass voting rights legislation and restore abortion rights stripped by the fall of Roe v. Wade.\n\n\"America has tried these failed policies before. And we are not going back. We're not going back,\" Harris said, shaking her head no as the crowd cheered \"we're not going back.\"\n\nRepublicans, who still control Georgia's state government, counter that Biden's lagging popularity and concern over higher consumer prices and immigration will transfer to Harris in the historically conservative state.\n\nBut they concede that the landscape suddenly looks much closer to 2020 - when Biden won by about 0.25 percentage points -- than when Trump was riding high after the Republican National Convention and surviving an assassination attempt.\n\n\"Trump was going to win Georgia. It was over,\" said Republican consultant Brian Robinson. \"The Democrats have a chance here for a reset.\"\n\nAnd Trump is not taking chances. Earlier Tuesday, the former president announced that he would come to Atlanta on Saturday for a rally in the same Georgia State arena.\n\nRobinson said Harris still has plenty of liabilities, including the progressive positions she took in her failed 2020 primary campaign and her various rhetorical stumbles. But he said Harris so far in this campaign has been \"in command,\" and if that continues, \"we have a new ballgame and she will be competitive in Georgia.\"\n\nTrump campaign spokesperson Karoline Leavitt dismissed Harris as \"just as weak, failed and incompetent as Joe Biden\" and said the vice president would have to explain her support of Biden administration policies that \"hurt working families in Georgia over the past four years.\"\n\nThe campaign and Georgia Democratic officials have 24 offices across the state, including two added last weekend in metro Atlanta. Trump and the Republican National Committee opened their first Georgia offices only recently.\n\nIn a call with supporters after her speech, Harris thanked them for their work and noted early voting starts in some states in just 38 days.\n\n\"This is a sprint,\" she said. \"And we know what we need to do to cross the finish line.\"\n\nThe fast-growing, diversifying Atlanta suburbs and exurbs offer the most opportunity for swings, especially from GOP-leaning moderates disenchanted with Trump.\n\nFor Harris, that means depending on voters as varied as Michael Sleister, a white suburbanite, and Allen Smith, a Black man who lives not far from downtown Atlanta.\n\nSleister, who considers himself an independent, has lived in Forsyth County for 35 years. \"I've voted Republican many times in my life,\" he said, but not since the GOP took a rightward turn during President Barack Obama's administration.\n\n\"Now I see the Republican Party as representing a direct threat to my grandchildren,\" he said, adding that he sees Trump \"as just a horrible person.\"\n\nSmith is a 41-year-old Atlanta native who has become a first-time campaign volunteer since Harris became the likely nominee.\n\n\"I was driving when I heard the news about President Biden endorsing her, and I started pounding my fist -- I decided right then I would do whatever I could to help her get elected,\" Smith said.", "source": {"uri": "wsav.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "WSAV News 3"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kamala_Harris", "type": "person", {"uri": "2024-07-438925785", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "02:02:01", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T02:02:01Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T00:26:29Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.729411780834198, "url": "https://www.thenationalherald.com/at-boisterous-georgia-rally-harris-says-she-will-show-trump-what-real-leadership-looks-like/", "title": "At Boisterous Georgia Rally, Harris Dares Trump to 'Say It to my Face' and Debate Her", "body": "ATLANTA -- Vice President Kamala Harris told a cheering, boisterous, packed Atlanta arena on Tuesday that the next 98 days would be a fight, but they'd win come November, as she taunted Donald Trump for wavering on whether he'd show up for their upcoming debate.\n\n\"The momentum in this race is shifting,\" the likely nominee said. \"And there are signs Donald Trump is feeling it.\"\n\nLittle more than a week ago, Georgia appeared to be slipping out of the Democrats' reach: President Joe Biden's campaign pledged to concentrate more on holding the Midwestern \"blue wall\" states and indicated they might be willing to forsake \"Sun Belt\" battlegrounds. But now that Biden has bowed out of the race and Harris is the likely nominee, Democrats are expressing new hopes of an expanded electoral map.\n\nHarris hasn't yet formally seized the Democrat nomination, though she is the only person who met the qualifications to vie for it, the Democratic National Committee announced Tuesday, and will all-but-certainly clinch it come Monday when the party concludes a virtual roll call vote. Her pick of a running mate is also expected by early next week when Harris plans to begin a seven-stop tour of battleground states to hold rallies alongside her vice presidential nominee.\n\nIn the state that delivered Biden his narrowest victory margin in 2020, Harris pulled off what has been a signature Trump event: A big, loud rally full of supporters cheering her name, as she mocked her rival and his running mate JD Vance as \"just plain weird,\" and derided their policies as backward, outdated and dangerous.\n\nHarris mentioned Trump's efforts to stop the passage of an immigration bill that had bipartisan support and would have been among the strongest border security in decades. She said she'd work to push the bill across the finish line. \"I will bring back the border security bill that Donald Trump killed and I will sign it and show Donald Trump what real leadership looks like.\"\n\nTrump earlier said he'd debate Harris, but is now questioning the value of a meetup and saying he \"probably\" will debate her, but he \"can also make a case for not doing it.\"\n\nHarris seized on it. \"So he won't debate me, but he and his running mate have a lot to say about me,\" she said. \"And by the way, don't you find some of their stuff to just be plain weird.\"\n\n\"Well Donald,\" she said, addressing him head-on. \"I do hope you'll reconsider. Meet me on the debate stage ... because as the saying goes, if you've got something to say, say it to my face.\" Trump has suggested the Sept. 10 debate on ABC News should be moved to a different network, calling ABC \"fake news.\"\n\nThe roughly 8,000-capacity basketball arena at Georgia State University was filled to its rafters with voters waving signs, dancing to the Harris campaign soundtrack and a performance by Megan Thee Stallion. Such an atmosphere would not have been possible just 10 days ago, with the party reeling over whether the 81-year-old Biden would remain in the race after a dismal performance magnified concerns about his age and abilities and ultimately ended his campaign.\n\n\"This is like Barack Obama 2008 on steroids for me,\" said Mildred Hobson Doss, a 59-year-old who came downtown from suburban Lilburn. \"I would have voted for President Biden again. But we are ready.\"\n\nHarris' campaign argues her appeal to young people, working-age women and non-white voters has scrambled the dynamics in Georgia and other states that are demographically similar, from North Carolina to Nevada and Arizona.\n\nIn a strategy memo released after the president left the race, Harris campaign chair Jen O'Malley Dillon, who held the same role for Biden, reaffirmed the importance of winning Michigan, Wisconsin and Pennsylvania, a trio of industrial states that have formed the traditional Democratic blue wall.\n\nBut she also argued that the vice president's place atop the ticket \"opens up additional persuadable voters\" and described them as \"disproportionately Black, Latino and under 30\" in places like Georgia.\n\n\"The energy is infectious,\" said Georgia Democratic Chairwoman Nikema Williams, a congresswoman from Atlanta. \"My phone has been blowing up. People want to be part of this movement.\"\n\nHarris began Tuesday with her days as a prosecutor -- setting up the contrast between the law and Trump's many legal problems and misdeeds. But she also aggressively defended the Biden administration's record and she'd work to pass voting rights legislation and work to restore reproductive rights stripped by the fall of Roe v. Wade.\n\n\"America has tried these failed policies before. And we are not going back. We're not going back,\" she said, shaking her head no as the crowd cheered \"we're not going back.\"\n\nRepublicans, who still control Georgia's state government, counter that Biden's lagging popularity and concern over higher consumer prices and immigration will transfer to Harris in the historically conservative state.\n\nBut they concede that the landscape suddenly looks much closer to 2020 - when Biden won by about 0.25 percentage points -- than when Trump was riding high after the Republican National Convention and surviving an assassination attempt.\n\n\"Trump was going to win Georgia. It was over,\" said Republican consultant Brian Robinson. \"The Democrats have a chance here for a reset.\"\n\nAnd Trump is not taking chances. Earlier Tuesday, the former president announced that he would come to Atlanta on Saturday for a rally in the same Georgia State arena.\n\nRobinson said Harris still has plenty of liabilities, including the progressive positions she took in her failed 2020 primary campaign and her various rhetorical stumbles. But he said Harris so far in this campaign has been \"in command,\" and if that continues, \"we have a new ballgame and she will be competitive in Georgia.\"\n\nTrump campaign spokesperson Karoline Leavitt dismissed Harris as \"just as weak, failed and incompetent as Joe Biden\" and said the vice president would have to explain her support of Biden administration policies that \"hurt working families in Georgia over the past four years.\"\n\nThe campaign and Georgia Democratic officials have 24 offices across the state, including two added last weekend in metro Atlanta. Trump and the Republican National Committee opened their first Georgia offices only recently.\n\nIn a call with supporters after her speech, Harris thanked them for their work and noted early voting starts in some states in just 38 days.\n\n\"This is a sprint,\" she said. \"And we know what we need to do to cross the finish line.\"\n\nThe fast-growing, diversifying Atlanta suburbs and exurbs offer the most opportunity for swings, especially from GOP-leaning moderates disenchanted with Trump.\n\nFor Harris, that means depending on voters as varied as Michael Sleister, a white suburbanite, and Allen Smith, a Black man who lives not far from downtown Atlanta.\n\nSleister, who considers himself an independent, has lived in Forsyth County for 35 years. \"I've voted Republican many times in my life,\" he said, but not since the GOP took a rightward turn during President Barack Obama's administration.\n\n\"Now I see the Republican Party as representing a direct threat to my grandchildren,\" he said, adding that he sees Trump \"as just a horrible person.\"\n\nSmith is a 41-year-old Atlanta native who has become a first-time campaign volunteer since Harris became the {"uri": "2024-07-438925490", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "02:00:53", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T02:00:53Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T01:42:17Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7254902124404907, "url": "https://www.register-herald.com/news/nation_world/at-boisterous-georgia-rally-harris-dares-trump-to-say-it-to-my-face-and-show/article_08d4d043-9447-5b38-80bd-a1acf68f09c5.html", "title": "At boisterous Georgia rally, Harris dares Trump to 'say it to my face' and show up for their debate", "body": "ATLANTA (AP) -- Vice President Kamala Harris told a cheering, boisterous, packed Atlanta arena on Tuesday that the next 98 days would be a fight, but they'd win come November, as she taunted Donald Trump for wavering on whether he'd show up for their upcoming debate.\n\n\"The momentum in this race is shifting,\" the likely nominee said. \"And there are signs Donald Trump is feeling it.\"\n\nLittle more than a week ago, Georgia appeared to be slipping out of the Democrats' reach: President Joe Biden's campaign pledged to concentrate more on holding the Midwestern \"blue wall\" states and indicated they might be willing to forsake \"Sun Belt\" battlegrounds. But now that Biden has bowed out of the race and Harris is the likely nominee, Democrats are expressing new hopes of an expanded electoral map.\n\nIn the state that delivered Biden his narrowest victory margin in 2020, Harris pulled off what has been a signature Trump event: A big, loud rally full of supporters cheering her name, as she mocked her rival and his running mate JD Vance as \"just plain weird,\" and derided their policies as backward, outdated and dangerous.\n\nTrump earlier said he'd debate Harris, but is now questioning the value of a meetup and saying he \"probably\" will debate her, but he \"can also make a case for not doing it.\"\n\nHarris seized on it. \"So he won't debate me, but he and his running mate have a lot to say about me,\" she said. \"And by the way, don't you find some of their stuff to just be plain weird.\"\n\n\"Well Donald,\" she said, addressing him head-on. \"I do hope you'll reconsider. Meet me on the debate stage ... because as the saying goes, if you've got something to say, say it to my face.\" Trump has suggested the Sept. 10 debate on ABC News should be moved to a different network, calling ABC \"fake news.\"\n\nHarris hasn't yet formally seized the Democrat nomination, though she is the only person who met the qualifications to vie for it, the Democratic National Committee announced Tuesday, and will all-but-certainly clinch it come Monday when the party concludes a virtual roll call vote. Her pick of a running mate is also expected by early next week when Harris plans to begin a seven-stop tour of battleground states to hold rallies alongside her vice presidential nominee.\n\nOn Tuesday, the roughly 8,000-capacity basketball arena at Georgia State University was filled to its rafters with voters waving signs, dancing to the Harris campaign soundtrack and a performance by Megan Thee Stallion. Such an atmosphere would not have been possible just 10 days ago, with the party reeling over whether the 81-year-old Biden would remain in the race after a dismal performance magnified concerns about his age and abilities and ultimately ended his campaign.\n\n\"This is like Barack Obama 2008 on steroids for me,\" said Mildred Hobson Doss, a 59-year-old who came downtown from suburban Lilburn. \"I would have voted for President Biden again. But we are ready.\"\n\nHarris' campaign argues her appeal to young people, working-age women and non-white voters has scrambled the dynamics in Georgia and other states that are demographically similar, from North Carolina to Nevada and Arizona.\n\nIn a strategy memo released after the president left the race, Harris campaign chair Jen O'Malley Dillon, who held the same role for Biden, reaffirmed the importance of winning Michigan, Wisconsin and Pennsylvania, a trio of industrial states that have formed the traditional Democratic blue wall.\n\nBut she also argued that the vice president's place atop the ticket \"opens up additional persuadable voters\" and described them as \"disproportionately Black, Latino and under 30\" in places like Georgia.\n\n\"The energy is infectious,\" said Georgia Democratic Chairwoman Nikema Williams, a congresswoman from Atlanta. \"My phone has been blowing up. People want to be part of this movement.\"\n\nHarris began Tuesday with her days as a prosecutor -- setting up the contrast between the law and Trump's many legal problems and misdeeds. But she also aggressively defended the Biden administration's record and said she would work to pass voting rights legislation and restore abortion rights stripped by the fall of Roe v. Wade.\n\n\"America has tried these failed policies before. And we are not going back. We're not going back,\" Harris said, shaking her head no as the crowd cheered \"we're not going back.\"\n\nRepublicans, who still control Georgia's state government, counter that Biden's lagging popularity and concern over higher consumer prices and immigration will transfer to Harris in the historically conservative state.\n\nBut they concede that the landscape suddenly looks much closer to 2020 - when Biden won by about 0.25 percentage points -- than when Trump was riding high after the Republican National Convention and surviving an assassination attempt.\n\n\"Trump was going to win Georgia. It was over,\" said Republican consultant Brian Robinson. \"The Democrats have a chance here for a reset.\"\n\nAnd Trump is not taking chances. Earlier Tuesday, the former president announced that he would come to Atlanta on Saturday for a rally in the same Georgia State arena.\n\nRobinson said Harris still has plenty of liabilities, including the progressive positions she took in her failed 2020 primary campaign and her various rhetorical stumbles. But he said Harris so far in this campaign has been \"in command,\" and if that continues, \"we have a new ballgame and she will be competitive in Georgia.\"\n\nTrump campaign spokesperson Karoline Leavitt dismissed Harris as \"just as weak, failed and incompetent as Joe Biden\" and said the vice president would have to explain her support of Biden administration policies that \"hurt working families in Georgia over the past four years.\"\n\nThe campaign and Georgia Democratic officials have 24 offices across the state, including two added last weekend in metro Atlanta. Trump and the Republican National Committee opened their first Georgia offices only recently.\n\nIn a call with supporters after her speech, Harris thanked them for their work and noted early voting starts in some states in just 38 days.\n\n\"This is a sprint,\" she said. \"And we know what we need to do to cross the finish line.\"\n\nThe fast-growing, diversifying Atlanta suburbs and exurbs offer the most opportunity for swings, especially from GOP-leaning moderates disenchanted with Trump.\n\nFor Harris, that means depending on voters as varied as Michael Sleister, a white suburbanite, and Allen Smith, a Black man who lives not far from downtown Atlanta.\n\nSleister, who considers himself an independent, has lived in Forsyth County for 35 years. \"I've voted Republican many times in my life,\" he said, but not since the GOP took a rightward turn during President Barack Obama's administration.\n\n\"Now I see the Republican Party as representing a direct threat to my grandchildren,\" he said, adding that he sees Trump \"as just a horrible person.\"\n\nSmith is a 41-year-old Atlanta native who has become a first-time campaign volunteer since Harris became the likely nominee.\n\n\"I was driving when I heard the news about President Biden endorsing her, and I started pounding my fist -- I decided right then I would do whatever I could to help her get elected,\" Smith said.\n\nLong reported from Washington. Follow the AP's coverage of the 2024 election at https://apnews.com/hub/election-2024.", "source": {"uri": "register-herald.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Beckley Register-Herald"}, "authors": Asked before arriving in Atlanta whether she has chosen a running mate, Harris told reporters: \"Not yet.\"\n\nBut her VP search apparently has accelerated, with Harris and her new running mate due to travel to multiple battleground states next week, US media reported, citing people familiar with the plans.\n\nAs for her evening rally in Atlanta, \"we do view Georgia as very competitive,\" Harris campaign battleground states director Dan Kanninen told reporters Monday.\n\nIn her speech, Harris will discuss \"the state of the race, reiterating that she is the underdog in this race but has real momentum and grassroots enthusiasm at her side,\" a campaign official said on background Tuesday, adding Harris is expected to call out Trump for so far refusing to honor his commitment to debate.\n\nIn a sign the southern state will be bitterly fought over, Trump and his running mate J.D. Vance announced they would hold their own rally in Atlanta on Saturday.\n\n\"Kamala Harris and her complicit cronies have made the great people of Georgia pay a hefty price for their woke policies,\" the Trump campaign said in a statement Tuesday.\n\nHarris took over a bleak electoral map from the faltering Biden, with Democrats' hopes entirely based on the three Rust Belt post-industrial states of Michigan, Wisconsin and Pennsylvania.\n\nBut they are now looking hopefully again at other \"sunbelt\" states such as Georgia, Arizona and Nevada, all of which Democrats narrowly won in the 2020 election, her campaign said.\n\nVance addressed a rally Tuesday in Henderson, Nevada where the Republican swiftly attacked Harris as \"dangerously liberal,\" while Trump campaigns in Pennsylvania on Wednesday.\n\n'Sucker punch'\n\nIn Atlanta, Harris made an unscheduled stop at a restaurant known for its soul food and featuring photographs of prominent African-Americans on the walls, including civil rights icon Martin Luther King Jr.\n\nAdding some on-stage glitz for younger voters will be Megan Thee Stallion and fellow hip-hop star Quavo, frontman for the now-defunct Georgia group Migos. The two are the latest in a series of celebrity backers for Harris.\n\n\"Hotties I'm performing for THEE Kamala Harris today in Atlanta!!\" Megan posted on X.\n\nWith Harris admitting Democrats are the \"underdogs,\" the question is now whether a vice president who recorded historically low approval ratings -- but is seeing a rapid improvement as a candidate -- can maintain momentum until November.\n\nVance -- himself facing a bumpy first week amid reports the Republican Party has buyer's remorse over his naming to the ticket -- admitted that Harris's last-minute entry was a \"sucker punch,\" the Washington Post reported.\n\nThe race had seemed set to feature former president Trump, 78, against incumbent Biden, 81, but the Democrat's withdrawal due to concerns over his age now {"uri": "2024-07-438975963", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "03:37:55", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T03:37:55Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T01:42:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7215686440467834, "url": "https://www.yahoo.com/news/harris-hold-rally-georgia-campaign-091910754.html", "title": "Harris becomes presumptive Democratic nominee, rails at Trump for not committing to debate", "body": "Vice President Kamala Harris is the presumptive Democratic nominee in the 2024 election, the Democratic National Committee (DNC) announced Tuesday night.\n\nHarris was the only candidate to qualify for the Democratic party's presidential nominating ballot, the party said.\n\nAcross the country, 3,923 delegates petitioned to make Harris the Democratic nominee, according to the DNC, which noted Harris secured the support of 99% of participating delegates.\n\nThe virtual roll call to make Harris the official Democratic nominee will begin Thursday, Aug. 1, and will end on Monday, Aug. 5.\n\nThe news of her presumed nomination comes after Harris took the stage at her Atlanta rally on Tuesday, marking her 15th trip to Georgia since taking office and her first trip to the battleground state since launching her own presidential bid.\n\n\"The path to the White House runs right through this state,\" Harris said of Georgia, adding, \"You all helped us win in 2020, and we're going to do it again in 2024.\"\n\nHarris called out former President Donald Trump for refusing to honor his commitment to the upcoming presidential debate, which ABC News will host in September.\n\n\"Well, Donald,\" she said with a smirk as the crowd of more than 10,000 erupted in applause and cheers.\n\n\"I do hope you'll reconsider to meet me on the debate stage because as the saying goes, if you've got something to say ... say it to my face,\" Harris said pointing to her face, with a huge grin.\n\nHarris addressed topics from immigration policy, where she vowed to pass a bipartisan immigration bill if elected, to strengthening the middle class and lowering the costs of essential items.\n\n\"On day one, I will take on price gouging and bring down costs,\" Harris said. \"We will ban more of those hidden fees and surprise late charges that banks and other companies use to pad their profits. We will take on corporate landlords and cap unfair rent increases. And we will take on big pharma to cap prescription drug costs for all Americans,\" she continued.\n\nHarris was joined by Sens. Jon Ossoff and Raphael Warnock, former Rep. Stacey Abrams, and several other special guests, including Migos rapper Quavo and a graduate of Morehouse College, a historically Black university.\n\nRapper Megan Thee Stallion performed at the Atlanta rally, getting the crowd energized with a performance of her hit song \"Savage\" and praising Harris as the would-be first Black, female president.\n\nOn a call with reporters ahead of her trip, Harris' campaign said Georgia, a formerly red state that voted blue in the last presidential election, is still \"in play.\"\n\n\"The vice president is energizing and mobilizing our base,\" said Dan Kanninen, the campaign's battleground states director. \"Having a candidate who can mobilize our key Biden-Harris coalition, talking about the issues that resonate with Georgians ... make that state in play.\"\n\nMORE: Harris' candidacy has led to surge in Black voter enthusiasm. It could make a difference in swing states\n\nSince President Joe Biden announced earlier this month that he was leaving the 2024 race, Harris has secured commitments from enough delegates to become the presumptive nominee if they all honor their commitment when voting, according to ABC News reporting.\n\nThe trip to Georgia comes as the campaign reported raising $200 million in less than a week since Biden dropped his reelection bid and endorsed Harris. The campaign is also boasting 170,000 new volunteers who have signed up to back Harris. This past weekend to commemorate the 100-day mark from November's election, the campaign hosted 2,300 events across the battleground states with more than 29,000 volunteers participating.\n\nHarris' remarks at the rally followed a meeting with local reproductive rights leaders and activists.\n\nGeorgia played a crucial role in Biden's 2020 victory, going blue for the first time since 1992 due, in significant part, to organizing efforts from Abrams, who spent years spearheading get-out-the-vote efforts in Black communities. Harris' campaign will be looking to replicate success in Georgia by shoring up support among Black voters, a key group of voters that both Harris and former President Donald Trump will work to connect with as the November election approaches.\n\nMORE: In replacing Biden, Harris could keep blue states in the Democratic fold\n\nBiden only won the state by some 12,000 votes in 2020, a win heavily contested by Trump, who is currently in the midst of an election interference case in the state. Trump hasn't held a campaign event in Georgia since his debate with Biden in June.\n\nKanninen said that although the Harris campaign has achieved an impressive fundraising haul in a short amount of time, they are not getting \"comfortable.\"\n\n\"I continue to be very clear with our partners and with our own staff. This campaign will not get comfortable. We jumped in with just 100 days ago against an opponent who has shown he's willing to do anything to win,\" said Kannien. \"This is going to be an incredibly close race just like it was in 2020. But just like four years ago, we are going to win this thing.\"\n\nThe Harris campaign told reporters they expect the state to be just as \"competitive\" this election, claiming that their infrastructure in the state gives them an advantage.\n\n\"We expect it to be as close as competitive this year,\" said Communications Director Michael Tyler. \"That's why we have the team and the operation in place to make sure that we can turn out every single Harris voter in the state of Georgia.\"\n\nAccording to the campaign, they have more than 170 coordinated staff and 24 offices across the state with three of those opening this past weekend. The Trump campaign only recently opened its first campaign office in the state in June.\n\n\"We're making these investments across the entire map because the data is clear. We have multiple pathways to 270 electoral votes,\" said Kanninen. \"The vice president is strong in both the blue wall and in the Sun Belt and we are running hard in both.\"", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "2024-07-438937578", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "02:25:44", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T02:25:44Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T01:40:56Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7137255072593689, "url": "https://www.kulr8.com/news/national/say-it-to-my-face-harris-dares-trump-as-white-house-battle-deepens/article_a21107fd-3723-5988-a6f2-542403f5c625.html", "title": "'Say it to my face,' Harris dares Trump as White House battle deepens", "body": "US Vice President Kamala Harris, the presumptive Democratic presidential nominee, told a large crowd in Atlanta, Georgia that 'the baton is in our hands'\n\nUS presidential hopeful Kamala Harris launched a searing attack on Donald Trump Tuesday, telling her biggest campaign rally yet that the momentum was shifting in the White House race and daring the Republican to debate her face to face.\n\nVice President Harris's trip to Atlanta, Georgia, comes as reenergized Democrats regard the swing state as being in play again, after it looked beyond hope under President Joe Biden before his shock withdrawal from the 2024 election.\n\nThe presumptive Democratic nominee is aiming to expand the party's 2024 battleground map and appeal to young Black voters, delivering a firm, 20-minute speech to about 10,000 supporters in a packed arena and pledging Americans \"are not going back\" to the \"failed policies\" of Trump.\n\n\"Now, the baton is in our hands,\" Harris said to loud applause. \"We have a fight in front of us... And we are the underdogs in this race.\"\n\nHarris's nascent presidential bid took off following Biden's July 21 exit from the race, with much of the party coalescing behind her and her campaign raising a staggering $200 million.\n\n\"The momentum in this race is shifting, and there are signs that Donald Trump is feeling it,\" she said.\n\nThe Republican nominee recently said he would forego political tradition and not debate Harris, and also unleashed a barrage of insults against his rival, calling her \"crazy\" and a \"bum.\"\n\n\"Well Donald, I do hope you'll reconsider to meet me on the debate stage, because as the saying goes, if you've got something to say, say it to my face,\" Harris said, to roars of approval.\n\nHarris also repeated her popular line about how, as a former prosecutor and California attorney general going up against predators and fraudsters, she knows \"Donald Trump's type.\"\n\n\"In this campaign, I will proudly put my record against his any day of the week,\" she said.\n\n- 'Extreme abortion bans' -\n\nWith just 98 days before the election, Harris is under pressure to announce her vice presidential pick. Asked Tuesday whether she had chosen one, Harris told reporters: \"Not yet.\"\n\nThe search must be nearing a conclusion, however, as her team announced Tuesday that Harris and her new running mate would campaign next week in battlegrounds Pennsylvania, Wisconsin, Michigan, North Carolina, Georgia, Arizona and Nevada.\n\nWith the White House race turned on its head, 59-year-old Harris on Tuesday unveiled her first television ad since replacing Biden, while the Trump camp released a dueling spot attacking her on the crucial election issue of immigration.\n\nHarris swatted away the attack, saying in her speech that while the Biden administration worked with conservatives to craft critical border legislation, Trump \"tanked\" it for political gain.\n\n\"Donald Trump does not care about border security,\" she said. \"He only cares about himself.\"\n\nHarris said if elected she would focus on key economic goals such as expanding affordable health care and tackling rising consumer costs.\n\nShe also attacked Trump, 78, over his \"extreme abortion bans,\" referring to restrictive new laws enacted in several states in the two years since the US Supreme Court -- featuring three justices nominated by Trump -- stripped constitutional protections for abortion.\n\n- Georgia in play -\n\nAs for Georgia's potential competitiveness, Harris insisted \"the path to the White House runs right through this state.\"\n\nIn a sign the southern state will be bitterly contested, Trump and his running mate J.D. Vance announced they would hold their own rally Saturday in Atlanta.\n\n\"Kamala Harris and her complicit cronies have made the great people of Georgia pay a hefty price for their woke policies,\" the Trump campaign said Tuesday.\n\nHarris took over a bleak electoral map from the faltering Biden, with Democrats' hopes entirely based on the three Rust Belt post-industrial states of Michigan, Wisconsin and Pennsylvania.\n\nBut they are now looking again at other \"sunbelt\" states such as Georgia, Arizona and Nevada, all of which Democrats narrowly won in 2020.\n\nVance addressed a rally Tuesday in Henderson, Nevada, where he attacked Harris as \"dangerously liberal,\" while Trump campaigns in Pennsylvania on Wednesday.\n\nAdding some Atlanta glitz for younger voters was Megan Thee Stallion, the hip-hop star who performed before Harris took the stage.\n\ndk-mlm/aha\n\nMore from this section\n\nChurch of Scientology Forum on the Need for Sustainability\n\nInvestigation finds at {"uri": "8251578044", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "01:45:08", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T01:45:08Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T01:42:48Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7098039388656616, "url": "https://mb.com.ph/2024/7/31/at-boisterous-georgia-rally-harris-dares-trump-to-say-it-to-my-face-and-debate-her", "title": "At boisterous Georgia rally, Harris dares Trump to 'say it to my face' and debate her", "body": "ATLANTA (AP) -- Vice President Kamala Harris told a cheering, boisterous, packed Atlanta arena on Tuesday that the next 98 days would be a fight, but they'd win come November, as she taunted Donald Trump for wavering on whether he'd show up for their upcoming debate.\n\nVice President Kamala Harris admires the crowd suring a campaign rally, Tuesday, July 30, 2024, in Atlanta. (AP Photo/John Bazemore)\n\n\"The momentum in this race is shifting,\" the likely nominee said. \"And there are signs Donald Trump is feeling it.\"\n\nLittle more than a week ago, Georgia appeared to be slipping out of the Democrats' reach: President Joe Biden's campaign pledged to concentrate more on holding the Midwestern \"blue wall\" states and indicated they might be willing to forsake \"Sun Belt\" battlegrounds. But now that Biden has bowed out of the race and Harris is the likely nominee, Democrats are expressing new hopes of an expanded electoral map.\n\nHarris hasn't yet formally seized the Democrat nomination, though she is the only person who met the qualifications to vie for it, the Democratic National Committee announced Tuesday, and will all-but-certainly clinch it come Monday when the party concludes a virtual roll call vote. Her pick of a running mate is also expected by early next week when Harris plans to begin a seven-stop tour of battleground states to hold rallies alongside her vice presidential nominee.\n\nIn the state that delivered Biden his narrowest victory margin in 2020, Harris pulled off what has been a signature Trump event: A big, loud rally full of supporters cheering her name, as she mocked her rival and his running mate JD Vance as \"just plain weird,\" and derided their policies as backward, outdated and dangerous.\n\nHarris mentioned Trump's efforts to stop the passage of an immigration bill that had bipartisan support and would have been among the strongest border security in decades. She said she'd work to push the bill across the finish line. \"I will bring back the border security bill that Donald Trump killed and I will sign it and show Donald Trump what real leadership looks like.\"\n\nTrump earlier said he'd debate Harris, but is now questioning the value of a meetup and saying he \"probably\" will debate her, but he \"can also make a case for not doing it.\"\n\nHarris seized on it. \"So he won't debate me, but he and his running mate have a lot to say about me,\" she said. \"And by the way, don't you find some of their stuff to just be plain weird.\"\n\n\"Well Donald,\" she said, addressing him head-on. \"I do hope you'll reconsider. Meet me on the debate stage ... because as the saying goes, if you've got something to say, say it to my face.\" Trump has suggested the Sept. 10 debate on ABC News should be moved to a different network, calling ABC \"fake news.\"\n\nThe roughly 8,000-capacity basketball arena at Georgia State University was filled to its rafters with voters waving signs, dancing to the Harris campaign soundtrack and a performance by Megan Thee Stallion. Such an atmosphere would not have been possible just 10 days ago, with the party reeling over whether the 81-year-old Biden would remain in the race after a dismal performance magnified concerns about his age and abilities and ultimately ended his campaign.\n\n\"This is like Barack Obama 2008 on steroids for me,\" said Mildred Hobson Doss, a 59-year-old who came downtown from suburban Lilburn. \"I would have voted for President Biden again. But we are ready.\"\n\nHarris' campaign argues her appeal to young people, working-age women and non-white voters has scrambled the dynamics in Georgia and other states that are demographically similar, from North Carolina to Nevada and Arizona.\n\nIn a strategy memo released after the president left the race, Harris campaign chair Jen O'Malley Dillon, who held the same role for Biden, reaffirmed the importance of winning Michigan, Wisconsin and Pennsylvania, a trio of industrial states that have formed the traditional Democratic blue wall.\n\nBut she also argued that the vice president's place atop the ticket \"opens up additional persuadable voters\" and described them as \"disproportionately Black, Latino and under 30\" in places like Georgia.\n\n\"The energy is infectious,\" said Georgia Democratic Chairwoman Nikema Williams, a congresswoman from Atlanta. \"My phone has been blowing up. People want to be part of this movement.\"\n\nHarris began Tuesday with her days as a prosecutor -- setting up the contrast between the law and Trump's many legal problems and misdeeds. But she also aggressively defended the Biden administration's record and she'd work to pass voting rights legislation and work to restore reproductive rights stripped by the fall of Roe v. Wade.\n\n\"America has tried these failed policies before. And we are not going back. We're not going back,\" she said, shaking her head no as the crowd cheered \"we're not going back.\"\n\nRepublicans, who still control Georgia's state government, counter that Biden's lagging popularity and concern over higher consumer prices and immigration will transfer to Harris in the historically conservative state.\n\nBut they concede that the landscape suddenly looks much closer to 2020 - when Biden won by about 0.25 percentage points -- than when Trump was riding high after the Republican National Convention and surviving an assassination attempt.\n\n\"Trump was going to win Georgia. It was over,\" said Republican consultant Brian Robinson. \"The Democrats have a chance here for a reset.\"\n\nAnd Trump is not taking chances. Earlier Tuesday, the former president announced that he would come to Atlanta on Saturday for a rally in the same Georgia State arena.\n\nRobinson said Harris still has plenty of liabilities, including the progressive positions she took in her failed 2020 primary campaign and her various rhetorical stumbles. But he said Harris so far in this campaign has been \"in command,\" and if that continues, \"we have a new ballgame and she will be competitive in Georgia.\"\n\nTrump campaign spokesperson Karoline Leavitt dismissed Harris as \"just as weak, failed and incompetent as Joe Biden\" and said the vice president would have to explain her support of Biden administration policies that \"hurt working families in Georgia over the past four years.\"\n\nThe campaign and Georgia Democratic officials have 24 offices across the state, including two added last weekend in metro Atlanta. Trump and the Republican National Committee opened their first Georgia offices only recently.\n\nIn a call with supporters after her speech, Harris thanked them for their work and noted early voting starts in some states in just 38 days.\n\n\"This is a sprint,\" she said. \"And we know what we need to do to cross the finish line.\"\n\nThe fast-growing, diversifying Atlanta suburbs and exurbs offer the most opportunity for swings, especially from GOP-leaning moderates disenchanted with Trump.\n\nFor Harris, that means depending on voters as varied as Michael Sleister, a white suburbanite, and Allen Smith, a Black man who lives not far from downtown Atlanta.\n\nSleister, who considers himself an independent, has lived in Forsyth County for 35 years. \"I've voted Republican many times in my life,\" he said, but not since the GOP took a rightward turn during President Barack Obama's administration.\n\n\"Now I see the Republican Party as representing a direct threat to my grandchildren,\" he said, adding that he sees Trump \"as just a horrible person.\"\n\nSmith is a 41-year-old Atlanta native who has become a first-time campaign volunteer since Harris became the likely nominee.\n\n\"I was driving when I heard the news about President Biden endorsing her, and I started pounding my fist -- I decided right then I would do whatever I could to help her get elected,\" Smith said.", "source": {"uri": "mb.com.ph", "dataType": "news", "title": "Manila Bulletin"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kamala_Harris", "type": {"uri": "2024-07-438884577", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "00:32:47", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T00:32:47Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T00:32:20Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7098039388656616, "url": "https://indianexpress.com/article/world/at-georgia-rally-harris-says-she-will-show-trump-what-real-leadership-looks-like-9485701/", "title": "At boisterous Georgia rally, Harris says she will show Trump 'what real leadership looks like | World News - The Indian Express", "body": "Republicans, who still control Georgia's state government, counter that Biden's lagging popularity and concern over higher consumer prices and immigration will transfer to Harris in the historically conservative state.\n\nVice President Kamala Harris told a cheering, boisterous, packed arena on Tuesday that the next few months would be a serious fight and acknowledged the Democrats were right now the underdogs but assured the crowd they would win in November.\n\n\"We have a fight in front of us,\" the likely nominee said. \"The momentum in this race is shifting. And there are signs Donald Trump is feeling it.\" Little more than a week ago, Georgia appeared to be slipping out of the Democrats' reach: President Joe Biden's campaign pledged to concentrate more on holding the Midwestern \"blue wall\" states and indicated they might be willing to forsake \"Sun Belt\" battlegrounds.\n\nBut now that Biden has bowed out of the race and Harris is the likely nominee, Democrats are expressing new hopes of an expanded electoral map and welcoming the vice president to the state that delivered Biden his narrowest victory margin in 2020 with a show of political force intended to signal a new landscape against Trump.\n\nHarris said when she was reelected she was going to work to sign important legislation on immigration and \"show Donald Trump what real leadership looks like.\"\n\nThe roughly 8,000-capacity basketball arena at Georgia State University was filled to its rafters with thousands of voters waving signs, dancing to the Harris campaign soundtrack and celebrating an atmosphere that would not have been possible just 10 days ago, with the party reeling over whether the 81-year-old Biden would remain in the race after a dismal performance magnified concerns about his age and abilities.\n\n\"This is like Barack Obama 2008 on steroids for me,\" said Mildred Hobson Doss, a 59-year-old who came downtown from suburban Lilburn. \"I would have voted for President Biden again. But we are ready.\"\n\nAlso read | Trump says he 'probably' will debate Harris but can 'make a case for not.' Her team says he's scared\n\nHarris is hoping the rally, which featured a performance by hip-hop star Megan Thee Stallion, will help affirm her campaign's momentum. The campaign argues that Harris' appeal to young people, working-age women and non-white voters has scrambled the dynamics in Georgia and other states that are demographically similar, from North Carolina to Nevada and Arizona.\n\n\"The energy is infectious,\" said Georgia Democratic Chairwoman Nikema Williams, a congresswoman from Atlanta. \"My phone has been blowing up. People want to be part of this movement.\" In a strategy memo released after the president left the race, Harris campaign chair Jen O'Malley Dillon, who held the same role for Biden, reaffirmed the importance of winning Michigan, Wisconsin and Pennsylvania, a trio of industrial states that have formed the traditional Democratic blue wall.\n\nBut she also argued that the vice president's place atop the ticket \"opens up additional persuadable voters\" and described them as \"disproportionately Black, Latino and under 30\" in places like Georgia.\n\n\"This campaign is about freedom,\" said Georgia Sen. Raphael Warnock, who was there with his fellow Democratic Sen. Jon Ossoff. \"So the question is, do you want to be free? Or do you want to go back?\" \"When you show up, we win.\"\n\nRepublicans, who still control Georgia's state government, counter that Biden's lagging popularity and concern over higher consumer prices and immigration will transfer to Harris in the historically conservative state.\n\nAlso read | Why Kamala Harris is having a 'brat summer'\n\nBut they concede that the landscape suddenly looks much closer to 2020 - when Biden won by about 0.25 percentage points -- than when Trump was riding high after the Republican National Convention and surviving an assassination attempt.\n\n\"Trump was going to win Georgia. It was over,\" said Republican consultant Brian Robinson. \"The Democrats have a chance here for a reset.\" And Trump is not taking chances. Earlier Tuesday, the former president announced that he would come to Atlanta on Saturday for a rally in the same Georgia State arena.\n\nRobinson said Harris still has plenty of liabilities, including the progressive positions she took in her failed 2020 primary campaign and her various rhetorical stumbles. But he said Harris so far in this campaign has been \"in command,\" and if that continues, \"we have a new ballgame and she will be competitive in Georgia.\"\n\nTrump campaign spokesperson Karoline Leavitt dismissed Harris as \"just as weak, failed and incompetent as Joe Biden\" and said the vice president would have to explain her support of Biden administration policies that \"hurt working families in Georgia over the past four years.\"\n\nThe Harris campaign and Georgia Democratic officials have 24 offices across the state, including two added last weekend in metro Atlanta. Trump and the Republican National Committee opened their first Georgia offices only recently.\n\nDemocrats are betting that a combination of high turnout among traditional, core Democratic constituencies, as well as a strong showing in the suburbs and small pickups elsewhere, can be enough for Harris to carry Georgia.\n\nGeorgia Gov. Brian Kemp, a Republican, said in a recent interview that the best GOP campaigns can win comfortably in Georgia but bad efforts -- combined with strong Democratic campaigns -- lose. Kemp, for example, won reelection by 7.5 percentage points in 2022 over national Democratic star Stacey Abrams. Yet in the same election cycle, Georgians reelected Democratic Sen. Raphael Warnock over his Republican challenger Herschel Walker, who was endorsed by Trump.\n\nIn recent elections, Democrats have held wide advantages in the core of metro Atlanta, where Jayapal spoke. The party also performed well in Columbus and Savannah, as well as some rural, majority-Black counties. But Republicans dominated in other rural areas and small towns and cities -- where Trump has held multiple rallies in recent years.\n\nThe fast-growing, diversifying Atlanta suburbs and exurbs offer the most opportunity for swings, especially from GOP-leaning moderates disenchanted with Trump.\n\nAlso read | With Kamala Harris front and centre in US presidential race, I see myself in American politics for the first time\n\nFor Harris, that means depending on voters as varied as Michael Sleister, a white suburbanite, and Allen Smith, a Black man who lives not far from downtown Atlanta.\n\nSleister, who considers himself an independent, has lived in Forsyth County for 35 years. \"I've voted Republican many times in my life,\" he said, but not since the GOP took a rightward turn during President Barack Obama's administration.\n\n\"Now I see the Republican Party as representing a direct threat to my grandchildren,\" he said, adding that he sees Trump \"as just a horrible person.\" Smith is a 41-year-old Atlanta native who has become a first-time campaign volunteer since Harris became the likely nominee.\n\n\"I was driving when I heard the news about President Biden endorsing her, and I started pounding my fist -- I decided right then I would do whatever I could to help her get elected,\" Smith said.", "source": {"uri": "indianexpress.com", "dataType": "news",
