{"uri": "8251422068", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "22:29:23", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T22:29:23Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T22:24:55Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7058823704719543, "url": "https://www.hindustantimes.com/world-news/harris-targets-battleground-georgia-with-rappers-help-101722377808956.html", "title": "Harris targets battleground Georgia, with rappers' help", "body": "US presidential hopeful Kamala Harris hit the campaign trail Tuesday in Georgia, hoping to expand Democrats' battleground map against Donald Trump and appeal to young Black voters with an appearance by hip-hop star Megan Thee Stallion.\n\nVice President Harris's trip to Atlanta comes as reenergized Democrats regard the swing state as being in play again, after it looked beyond hope under President Joe Biden before his shock withdrawal from the 2024 election.\n\nShe will address what the Harris campaign described as the largest crowd of her nascent presidential bid, with an indoor arena packed with 10,000 supporters.\n\nWith the White House race now turned on its head, 59-year-old Harris on Tuesday released her first television ad since replacing Biden, while the Trump camp released a dueling spot attacking her on the crucial election issue of immigration.\n\nHarris, with just 98 days before the election, is under pressure to announce her vice presidential pick ahead of the Democratic Party's nominating convention in August. Asked before arriving in Atlanta whether she has chosen a running mate, Harris told reporters: \"Not yet.\"\n\nBut her VP search apparently has accelerated, with Harris and her new running mate due to travel to multiple battleground states next week, US media reported, citing people familiar with the plans.\n\nAs for her evening rally in Atlanta, \"we do view Georgia as very competitive,\" Harris campaign battleground states director Dan Kanninen told reporters Monday.\n\nIn her speech, Harris will discuss \"the state of the race, reiterating that she is the underdog in this race but has real momentum and grassroots enthusiasm at her side,\" a campaign official said on background Tuesday, adding Harris is expected to call out Trump for so far refusing to honor his commitment to debate.\n\nIn a sign the southern state will be bitterly fought over, Trump and his running mate J.D. Vance announced they would hold their own rally in Atlanta on Saturday.\n\n\"Kamala Harris and her complicit cronies have made the great people of Georgia pay a hefty price for their woke policies,\" the Trump campaign said in a statement Tuesday.\n\nHarris took over a bleak electoral map from the faltering Biden, with Democrats' hopes entirely based on the three Rust Belt post-industrial states of Michigan, Wisconsin and Pennsylvania.\n\nBut they are now looking hopefully again at other \"sunbelt\" states such as Georgia, Arizona and Nevada, all of which Democrats narrowly won in the 2020 election, her campaign said.\n\nVance addressed a rally Tuesday in Henderson, Nevada where the Republican swiftly attacked Harris as \"dangerously liberal,\" while Trump campaigns in Pennsylvania on Wednesday.\n\nIn Atlanta, Harris made an unscheduled stop at a restaurant known for its soul food and featuring photographs of prominent African-Americans on the walls, including civil rights icon Martin Luther King Jr.\n\nAdding some on-stage glitz for younger voters will be Megan Thee Stallion and fellow hip-hop star Quavo, frontman for the now-defunct Georgia group Migos. The two are the latest in a series of celebrity backers for Harris.\n\n\"Hotties I'm performing for THEE Kamala Harris today in Atlanta!!\" Megan posted on X.\n\nWith Harris admitting Democrats are the \"underdogs,\" the question is now whether a vice president who recorded historically low approval ratings but is seeing a rapid improvement as a candidate can maintain momentum until November.\n\nVance himself facing a bumpy first week amid reports the Republican Party has buyer's remorse over his naming to the ticket admitted that Harris's last-minute entry was a \"sucker punch,\" the Washington Post reported.\n\nThe race had seemed set to feature former president Trump, 78, against incumbent Biden, 81, but the Democrat's withdrawal due to concerns over his age now leaves Trump as the oldest major party nominee in US history.\n\ndk/mlm/bjt", "source": {"uri": "hindustantimes.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Hindustan Times"}, "authors": [], "concepts": {"uri": "8251509648", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "00:13:46", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T00:13:46Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T00:12:51Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7058823704719543, "url": "https://www.al.com/news/2024/07/kamala-harris-in-atlanta-calls-on-trump-to-debate-if-you-got-something-to-say-say-it-to-my-face.html", "title": "Kamala Harris in Atlanta calls on Trump to debate: 'If you got something to say, say it to my face'", "body": "Vice President Kamala Harris told a cheering, boisterous, packed arena on Tuesday that the next few months would be a serious fight and acknowledged the Democrats were right now the underdogs -- but assured the crowd they would win in November.\n\n\"We have a fight in front of us,\" the likely nominee said. \"The momentum in this race is shifting. And there are signs Donald Trump is feeling it.\"\n\nHarris called on Trump to face her in a debate.\n\n\"I do hope you'll reconsider to meet me on the debate stage. Because as the saying goes, if you got something to say, say it to my face,\" Harris said.\n\nA Trump spokesman has said that debate plans \"cannot be finalized until Democrats formally decide on their nominee.\"\n\nLittle more than a week before Harris' visit tonight, Georgia appeared to be slipping out of the Democrats' reach: President Joe Biden's campaign pledged to concentrate more on holding the Midwestern \"blue wall\" states and indicated they might be willing to forsake \"Sun Belt\" battlegrounds.\n\nBut now that Biden has bowed out of the race and Harris is the likely nominee, Democrats are expressing new hopes of an expanded electoral map and welcoming the vice president to the state that delivered Biden his narrowest victory margin in 2020 with a show of political force intended to signal a new landscape against Trump.\n\nHarris said when she was reelected she was going to work to sign important legislation on immigration and \"show Donald Trump what real leadership looks like.\"\n\nThe roughly 8,000-capacity basketball arena at Georgia State University was filled to its rafters with thousands of voters waving signs, dancing to the Harris campaign soundtrack and celebrating an atmosphere that would not have been possible just 10 days ago, with the party reeling over whether the 81-year-old Biden would remain in the race after a dismal performance magnified concerns about his age and abilities.\n\n\"This is like Barack Obama 2008 on steroids for me,\" said Mildred Hobson Doss, a 59-year-old who came downtown from suburban Lilburn. \"I would have voted for President Biden again. But we are ready.\"\n\nHarris is hoping the rally, which featured a performance by hip-hop star Megan Thee Stallion, will help affirm her campaign's momentum. The campaign argues that Harris' appeal to young people, working-age women and non-white voters has scrambled the dynamics in Georgia and other states that are demographically similar, from North Carolina to Nevada and Arizona.\n\n\"The energy is infectious,\" said Georgia Democratic Chairwoman Nikema Williams, a congresswoman from Atlanta. \"My phone has been blowing up. People want to be part of this movement.\"\n\nIn a strategy memo released after the president left the race, Harris campaign chair Jen O'Malley Dillon, who held the same role for Biden, reaffirmed the importance of winning Michigan, Wisconsin and Pennsylvania, a trio of industrial states that have formed the traditional Democratic blue wall.\n\nBut she also argued that the vice president's place atop the ticket \"opens up additional persuadable voters\" and described them as \"disproportionately Black, Latino and under 30'' in places like Georgia.\n\n\"This campaign is about freedom,\" said Georgia Sen. Raphael Warnock, who was there with his fellow Democratic Sen. Jon Ossoff. \"So the question is, do you want to be free? Or do you want to go back?\"\n\n\"When you show up, we win.\"\n\nRepublicans, who still control Georgia's state government, counter that Biden's lagging popularity and concern over higher consumer prices and immigration will transfer to Harris in the historically conservative state.\n\nBut they concede that the landscape suddenly looks much closer to 2020 - when Biden won by about 0.25 percentage points -- than when Trump was riding high after the Republican National Convention and surviving an assassination attempt.\n\n\"Trump was going to win Georgia. It was over,\" said Republican consultant Brian Robinson. \"The Democrats have a chance here for a reset.\"\n\nAnd Trump is not taking chances. Earlier Tuesday, the former president announced that he would come to Atlanta on Saturday for a rally in the same Georgia State arena.\n\nRobinson said Harris still has plenty of liabilities, including the progressive positions she took in her failed 2020 primary campaign and her various rhetorical stumbles. But he said Harris so far in this campaign has been \"in command,\" and if that continues, \"we have a new ballgame and she will be competitive in Georgia.\"\n\nTrump campaign spokesperson Karoline Leavitt dismissed Harris as \"just as weak, failed and incompetent as Joe Biden\" and said the vice president would have to explain her support of Biden administration policies that \"hurt working families in Georgia over the past four years.\"\n\nThe Harris campaign and Georgia Democratic officials have 24 offices across the state, including two added last weekend in metro Atlanta. Trump and the Republican National Committee opened their first Georgia offices only recently.\n\nDemocrats are betting that a combination of high turnout among traditional, core Democratic constituencies, as well as a strong showing in the suburbs and small pickups elsewhere, can be enough for Harris to carry Georgia.\n\nGeorgia Gov. Brian Kemp, a Republican, said in a recent interview that the best GOP campaigns can win comfortably in Georgia but bad efforts -- combined with strong Democratic campaigns -- lose. Kemp, for example, won reelection by 7.5 percentage points in 2022 over national Democratic star Stacey Abrams. Yet in the same election cycle, Georgians reelected Democratic Sen. Raphael Warnock over his Republican challenger Herschel Walker, who was endorsed by Trump.\n\nIn recent elections, Democrats have held wide advantages in the core of metro Atlanta, where Jayapal spoke. The party also performed well in Columbus and Savannah, as well as some rural, majority-Black counties. But Republicans dominated in other rural areas and small towns and cities -- where Trump has held multiple rallies in recent years.\n\nThe fast-growing, diversifying Atlanta suburbs and exurbs offer the most opportunity for swings, especially from GOP-leaning moderates disenchanted with Trump.\n\nFor Harris, that means depending on voters as varied as Michael Sleister, a white suburbanite, and Allen Smith, a Black man who lives not far from downtown Atlanta.\n\nSleister, who considers himself an independent, has lived in Forsyth County for 35 years. \"I've voted Republican many times in my life,\" he said, but not since the GOP took a rightward turn during President Barack Obama's administration.\n\n\"Now I see the Republican Party as representing a direct threat to my grandchildren,\" he said, adding that he sees Trump \"as just a horrible person.\"\n\nSmith is a 41-year-old Atlanta native who has become a first-time campaign volunteer since Harris became the likely nominee.\n\n\"I was driving when I heard the news about President Biden endorsing her, and I started pounding my fist -- I decided right then I would do whatever I could to help her get elected,\" Smith said.", {"uri": "2024-07-438930135", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "02:10:20", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T02:10:20Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T02:10:10Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7019608020782471, "url": "https://globalnation.inquirer.net/244183/say-it-to-my-face-harris-dares-trump-as-white-house-battle-deepens", "title": "'Say it to my face,' Harris dares Trump", "body": "ATLANTA - US presidential hopeful Kamala Harris launched a searing attack on Donald Trump Tuesday, telling her biggest campaign rally yet that the momentum was shifting in the White House race and daring the Republican to debate her face to face. Vice President Harris's trip to Atlanta, Georgia, comes as reenergized Democrats regard the swing state as being in play again, after it looked beyond hope under President Joe Biden before his shock withdrawal from the 2024 election. The presumptive Democratic nominee is aiming to expand the party's 2024 battleground map and appeal to young Black voters, delivering a firm, 20-minute speech to about 10,000 supporters in a packed arena and pledging Americans \"are not going back\" to the \"failed policies\" of Trump. \"Now, the baton is in our hands,\" Harris said to loud applause. \"We have a fight in front of us... And we are the underdogs in this race.\" Harris's nascent presidential bid took off following Biden's July 21 exit from the race, with much of the party coalescing behind her and her campaign raising a staggering $200 million. \"The momentum in this race is shifting, and there are signs that Donald Trump is feeling it,\" she said. The Republican nominee recently said he would forego political tradition and not debate Harris, and also unleashed a barrage of insults against his rival, calling her \"crazy\" and a \"bum.\" \"Well Donald, I do hope you'll reconsider to meet me on the debate stage, because as the saying goes, if you've got something to say, say it to my face,\" Harris said, to roars of approval. Harris also repeated her popular line about how, as a former prosecutor and California attorney general going up against predators and fraudsters, she knows \"Donald Trump's type.\" \"In this campaign, I will proudly put my record against his any day of the week,\" she said. With just 98 days before the election, Harris is under pressure to announce her vice presidential pick. Asked Tuesday whether she had chosen one, Harris told reporters: \"Not yet.\" The search must be nearing a conclusion, however, as her team announced Tuesday that Harris and her new running mate would campaign next week in battlegrounds Pennsylvania, Wisconsin, Michigan, North Carolina, Georgia, Arizona and Nevada. With the White House race turned on its head, 59-year-old Harris on Tuesday unveiled her first television ad since replacing Biden, while the Trump camp released a dueling spot attacking her on the crucial election issue of immigration. Harris swatted away the attack, saying in her speech that while the Biden administration worked with conservatives to craft critical border legislation, Trump \"tanked\" it for political gain. \"Donald Trump does not care about border security,\" she said. \"He only cares about himself.\" Harris said if elected she would focus on key economic goals such as expanding affordable health care and tackling rising consumer costs. She also attacked Trump, 78, over his \"extreme abortion bans,\" referring to restrictive new laws enacted in several states in the two years since the US Supreme Court -- featuring three justices nominated by Trump -- stripped constitutional protections for abortion. As for Georgia's potential competitiveness, Harris insisted \"the path to the White House runs right through this state.\" In a sign the southern state will be bitterly contested, Trump and his running mate J.D. Vance announced they would hold their own rally Saturday in Atlanta. \"Kamala Harris and her complicit cronies have made the great people of Georgia pay a hefty price for their woke policies,\" the Trump campaign said Tuesday. Harris took over a bleak electoral map from the faltering Biden, with Democrats' hopes entirely based on the three Rust Belt post-industrial states of Michigan, Wisconsin and Pennsylvania. But they are now looking again at other \"sunbelt\" states such as Georgia, Arizona and Nevada, all of which Democrats narrowly won in 2020. Vance addressed a rally Tuesday in Henderson, Nevada, where he attacked Harris as \"dangerously liberal,\" while Trump campaigns in Pennsylvania on Wednesday. She threw down the gauntlet to Republican candidate Donald Trump, challenging him to confront her face to face in a debate. Not only that, but she also brought out Megan Thee Stallion and Quavo for special appearances on stage, making it a memorable political event!\n\nHere's What VP Kamala Harris' Said About Trump At Atlanta Rally\n\nSpeaking to a lively crowd in a packed arena in Atlanta, Kamala Harris, as reported by the Associated Press, declared that the next 98 days leading up to the election would be a tough battle, but their victory was inevitable in November. She also mocked Donald Trump for his indecision about participating in the upcoming debate.\n\n\"The momentum in this race is shifting,\" the likely Democratic nominee said. \"And there are signs Donald Trump is feeling it.\"\n\nInitially agreeing to the debate with Harris, Trump has now expressed uncertainty about its significance, stating that he might participate but could also argue against it. Furthermore, Trump has proposed moving the scheduled Sept. 10 debate, set to air on ABC News, to a different network, accusing ABC of being biased and labeling it as \"fake news.\"\n\n\"So he won't debate me, but he and his running mate have a lot to say about me. And by the way, don't you find some of their stuff to just be plain weird.\" She added, \"Well Donald...I do hope you'll reconsider. Meet me on the debate stage ... because, as the saying goes, if you've got something to say, say it to my face.\"\n\nIn the state that delivered Biden his narrowest victory margin in 2020, Harris pulled off what has been a signature Trump event: A big, loud rally full of supporters cheering her name. While on stage, she mocked her rival and his running mate, JD Vance, as \"just plain weird\" and described their policies as backward, outdated, and dangerous.\n\nVP Harris Discusses What's Next In Her Race To The White House\n\nFor context, Harris hasn't yet formally seized the Democratic nomination. However, the Democratic National Committee announced on Tuesday that she is the only person who meets the qualifications to vie for it. This means she will all but certainly clinch it come Monday (August 5) when the party concludes a virtual roll call vote.\n\nHer pick of a running mate is also expected by early next week. At that time, Harris plans to begin a seven-stop tour of battleground states to hold rallies alongside her vice presidential nominee.\n\nHarris began Tuesday with her days as a prosecutor -- setting up the contrast between the law and Trump's many legal problems and misdeeds. But she also aggressively defended the Biden administration's record and said she would work to pass voting rights legislation and restore abortion rights stripped by the fall of Roe v. Wade.\n\n\"America has tried these failed policies before. And we are not going back. We're not going back,\" Harris said, shaking her head no as the crowd cheered \"we're not going back.\"\n\nSwipe below to see more clips from Kamala Harris' Atlanta rally.\n\nSpecial Guests At Atlanta Rally Included Megan Thee Stallion & Quavo\n\nOn Tuesday, the roughly 8,000-capacity basketball arena at Georgia State University was filled to its rafters with voters waving signs, dancing to the Harris campaign soundtrack 'Freedom' by Beyonc\u00e9, and a performance by Megan Thee Stallion.\n\nQuavo stepped to the mic and strongly endorsed the Vice President, citing his previous work with her on gun violence. He credited the politician for always standing \"on business.\"\n\n\"So if you never voted before, make sure you get out right now 'cause this the real one. And in the words of my brother Takeoff, let me get a 'Kamala,'\" Quavo said.\n\nGeorgia Senator Raphael Warnock also spoke passionately at the Atlanta rally about Kamala Harris' trek for the White House.\n\nThis week marks the second full one of Harris' campaign since first announcing her intent to replace President Joe Biden as the Democratic nominee in the White House race. {"uri": "8251820810", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "05:51:42", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T05:51:42Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T05:49:34Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6980392336845398, "url": "https://www.urdupoint.com/en/world/say-it-to-my-face-harris-dares-trump-as-wh-1848767.html", "title": "Say It To My Face, Harris Dares Trump As White House Battle Deepens - UrduPoint", "body": "Atlanta, (APP - UrduPoint / Pakistan Point News - 31st Jul, 2024) US presidential hopeful Kamala Harris launched a searing attack on Donald Trump Tuesday, telling her biggest campaign rally yet that the momentum was shifting in the White House race and daring the Republican to debate her face to face.\n\nVice President Harris's trip to Atlanta, Georgia, comes as reenergized Democrats regard the swing state as being in play again, after it looked beyond hope under President Joe Biden before his shock withdrawal from the 2024 election.\n\nThe presumptive Democratic nominee is aiming to expand the party's 2024 battleground map and appeal to young Black voters, delivering a firm, 20-minute speech to about 10,000 supporters in a packed arena and pledging Americans \"are not going back\" to the \"failed policies\" of Trump.\n\n\"Now, the baton is in our hands,\" Harris said to loud applause. \"We have a fight in front of us... And we are the underdogs in this race.\"\n\nThe Republican nominee recently said he would forego political tradition and not debate Harris, and also unleashed a barrage of insults against his rival, calling her \"crazy\" and a \"bum.\"\n\n\"Well Donald, I do hope you'll reconsider to meet me on the debate stage, because as the saying goes, if you've got something to say, say it to my face,\" Harris said, to roars of approval.\n\nHarris also repeated her popular line about how, as a former prosecutor and California attorney general going up against predators and fraudsters, she knows \"Donald Trump's type.\"\n\n\"In this campaign, I will proudly put my record against his any day of the week,\" she said.\n\nWith just 98 days before the election, Harris is under pressure to announce her vice presidential pick. Asked Tuesday whether she had chosen one, Harris told reporters: \"Not yet.\"\n\nThe search must be nearing a conclusion, however, as her team announced Tuesday that Harris and her new running mate would campaign next week in battlegrounds Pennsylvania, Wisconsin, Michigan, North Carolina, Georgia, Arizona and Nevada.\n\nHarris said if elected she would focus on key economic goals such as expanding affordable health care and tackling rising consumer costs.\n\nShe also attacked Trump, 78, over his \"extreme abortion bans,\" referring to restrictive new laws enacted in several states in the two years since the US Supreme Court -- featuring three justices nominated by Trump -- stripped constitutional protections for abortion.\n\nAs for Georgia's potential competitiveness, Harris insisted \"the path to the White House runs right through this state.\"\n\nIn a sign the southern state will be bitterly contested, Trump and his running mate J.D. Vance announced they would hold their own rally Saturday in Atlanta.\n\n\"Kamala Harris and her complicit cronies have made the great people of Georgia pay a hefty price for their woke policies,\" the Trump campaign said Tuesday.\n\nHarris took over a bleak electoral map from the faltering Biden, with Democrats' hopes entirely based on the three Rust Belt post-industrial states of Michigan, Wisconsin and Pennsylvania.\n\nBut they are now looking again at other \"sunbelt\" states such as Georgia, Arizona and Nevada, all of which Democrats narrowly won in 2020.\n\nVance addressed a rally Tuesday in Henderson, Nevada, where he attacked Harris as \"dangerously liberal,\" while Trump campaigns in Pennsylvania on Wednesday.\n\nAdding some Atlanta glitz for younger voters was Megan Thee {"uri": "8251610000", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "02:25:11", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T02:25:11Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T02:22:50Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6980392336845398, "url": "https://www.ktbs.com/news/national/say-it-to-my-face-harris-dares-trump-as-white-house-battle-deepens/article_da363662-e4e5-5e48-8074-030a7c905cc1.html", "title": "'Say it to my face,' Harris dares Trump as White House battle deepens", "body": "US Vice President Kamala Harris, the presumptive Democratic presidential nominee, told a large crowd in Atlanta, Georgia that 'the baton is in our hands'\n\nUS presidential hopeful Kamala Harris launched a searing attack on Donald Trump Tuesday, telling her biggest campaign rally yet that the momentum was shifting in the White House race and daring the Republican to debate her face to face.\n\nVice President Harris's trip to Atlanta, Georgia, comes as reenergized Democrats regard the swing state as being in play again, after it looked beyond hope under President Joe Biden before his shock withdrawal from the 2024 election.\n\nThe presumptive Democratic nominee is aiming to expand the party's 2024 battleground map and appeal to young Black voters, delivering a firm, 20-minute speech to about 10,000 supporters in a packed arena and pledging Americans \"are not going back\" to the \"failed policies\" of Trump.\n\n\"Now, the baton is in our hands,\" Harris said to loud applause. \"We have a fight in front of us... And we are the underdogs in this race.\"\n\nHarris's nascent presidential bid took off following Biden's July 21 exit from the race, with much of the party coalescing behind her and her campaign raising a staggering $200 million.\n\n\"The momentum in this race is shifting, and there are signs that Donald Trump is feeling it,\" she said.\n\nThe Republican nominee recently said he would forego political tradition and not debate Harris, and also unleashed a barrage of insults against his rival, calling her \"crazy\" and a \"bum.\"\n\n\"Well Donald, I do hope you'll reconsider to meet me on the debate stage, because as the saying goes, if you've got something to say, say it to my face,\" Harris said, to roars of approval.\n\nHarris also repeated her popular line about how, as a former prosecutor and California attorney general going up against predators and fraudsters, she knows \"Donald Trump's type.\"\n\n\"In this campaign, I will proudly put my record against his any day of the week,\" she said.\n\n- 'Extreme abortion bans' -\n\nWith just 98 days before the election, Harris is under pressure to announce her vice presidential pick. Asked Tuesday whether she had chosen one, Harris told reporters: \"Not yet.\"\n\nThe search must be nearing a conclusion, however, as her team announced Tuesday that Harris and her new running mate would campaign next week in battlegrounds Pennsylvania, Wisconsin, Michigan, North Carolina, Georgia, Arizona and Nevada.\n\nWith the White House race turned on its head, 59-year-old Harris on Tuesday unveiled her first television ad since replacing Biden, while the Trump camp released a dueling spot attacking her on the crucial election issue of immigration.\n\nHarris swatted away the attack, saying in her speech that while the Biden administration worked with conservatives to craft critical border legislation, Trump \"tanked\" it for political gain.\n\n\"Donald Trump does not care about border security,\" she said. \"He only cares about himself.\"\n\nHarris said if elected she would focus on key economic goals such as expanding affordable health care and tackling rising consumer costs.\n\nShe also attacked Trump, 78, over his \"extreme abortion bans,\" referring to restrictive new laws enacted in several states in the two years since the US Supreme Court -- featuring three justices nominated by Trump -- stripped constitutional protections for abortion.\n\n- Georgia in play -\n\nAs for Georgia's potential competitiveness, Harris insisted \"the path to the White House runs right through this state.\"\n\nIn a sign the southern state will be bitterly contested, Trump and his running mate J.D. Vance announced they would hold their own rally Saturday in Atlanta.\n\n\"Kamala Harris and her complicit cronies have made the great people of Georgia pay a hefty price for their woke policies,\" the Trump campaign said Tuesday.\n\nHarris took over a bleak electoral map from the faltering Biden, with Democrats' hopes entirely based on the three Rust Belt post-industrial states of Michigan, Wisconsin and Pennsylvania.\n\nBut they are now looking again at other \"sunbelt\" states such as Georgia, Arizona and Nevada, all of which Democrats narrowly won in 2020.\n\nVance addressed a rally Tuesday in Henderson, Nevada, where he attacked Harris as \"dangerously liberal,\" while Trump campaigns in Pennsylvania on Wednesday.\n\nAdding some Atlanta glitz for younger voters was Megan Thee Stallion, the hip-hop star who performed before Harris took the stage.\n\ndk-mlm/aha", "source": {"uri": "ktbs.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "KTBS"}, "authors": [{"uri": {"uri": "8251677191", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "03:42:02", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T03:42:02Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T03:41:22Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6980392336845398, "url": "https://www.atlantanewsfirst.com/2024/07/31/harris-holds-first-georgia-rally-candidate-will-return-next-week/", "title": "Harris holds first Georgia rally as candidate, will return next week", "body": "ATLANTA, Ga. (Atlanta News First) - Kamala Harris touched down in Georgia on Tuesday for a kickoff rally in a state she knows well.\n\n\"Oh, it's good to be back in Georgia,\" said Harris, taking the state to cheers from a crowd of several thousand. \"The path to the White House runs right through this state.\"\n\nHarris may be right. Georgia, with 16 electoral votes, will be a massive prize on Nov. 5 for either presumably her or Republican presidential nominee Donald Trump.\n\nTrump, alongside his new ticket-mate, Ohio Senator J.D. Vance, will host their own rally at the very same Georgia State University Convocation Center venue in downtown Atlanta on Saturday.\n\nThe state is especially important for Democrats, looking to hold the traditionally-red-turned-blue state after Georgia all but handed the 2020 election to Harris and President Joe Biden.\n\nWith her budding candidacy, Harris got some help at her rally from some high-powered names. Democratic leader Stacey Abrams spoke prior to Harris arrival, as did Atlanta Mayor Andre Dickens and Georgia Senators Raphael Warnock and Jon Ossoff.\n\nGrammy-winning artist Quavo spoke for Harris before she came on stage, as did Grammy-winner Megan Thee Stallion, who performed just prior to Harris coming out.\n\n\"You all helped us win in 2020 and we going to do it again in 2024,\" Harris told the crowd. \"I don't have to tell folks in Atlanta that generations of Americans before us led the fight for freedom. And now, the baton is in our hands.\"\n\nHarris laid out her plans to attack corporate land owners, a problem that Georgians face in particular. She also renewed her promise to slash bank fees and hidden charges, strengthen abortion protections, and sign the John Lewis Voting Rights Act as president if Congress passes it.\n\nAs she's done since launching her campaign, Harris played her past as a prosecutor against her presumptive opponent's multiple criminal convictions. It's a move that could play well with - or serve to further alienate - voters in Georgia, where Trump is facing one of his only remaining viable court cases in Fulton County.\n\n\"I took on perpetrators of all kinds,\" said Harris of her time as California's Attorney General. \"Predators who abused women, fraudsters who ripped off consumers, cheaters who broke the rules for their own gain. So hear me when I say, I know Donald Trump's type.\"\n\nHarris is expected to announce her pick for running mate as early as the end of the week. After, she and whoever her VP pick is, will embark on a tour of battleground states next week, including a stop in Savannah.", "source": {"uri": "atlantanewsfirst.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9774352", "eventUri": "eng-9774352", "location": {"type": "place", "label": {"eng": "Atlanta, Georgia"}, "country": {"type": "country", "label": {"eng": {"uri": "2024-07-438874550", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "00:11:26", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T00:11:26Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T00:06:38Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6941176652908325, "url": "https://www.telegraphindia.com/world/at-boisterous-georgia-rally-kamala-harris-says-she-will-show-donald-trump-what-real-leadership-looks-like/cid/2037460", "title": "At Georgia rally, Kamala says she will show Trump 'what real leadership looks like'", "body": "The roughly 8,000-capacity basketball arena at Georgia State University was filled to its rafters with thousands of voters waving signs, dancing to the Harris campaign soundtrack\n\nVice President Kamala Harris told a cheering, boisterous, packed arena on Tuesday that the next few months would be a serious fight and acknowledged the Democrats were right now the underdogs -- but assured the crowd they would win in November.\n\n\"We have a fight in front of us,\" the likely nominee said. \"The momentum in this race is shifting. And there are signs Donald Trump is feeling it.\"\n\nLittle more than a week ago, Georgia appeared to be slipping out of the Democrats' reach: President Joe Biden's campaign pledged to concentrate more on holding the Midwestern \"blue wall\" states and indicated they might be willing to forsake \"Sun Belt\" battlegrounds.\n\nBut now that Biden has bowed out of the race and Harris is the likely nominee, Democrats are expressing new hopes of an expanded electoral map and welcoming the vice president to the state that delivered Biden his narrowest victory margin in 2020 with a show of political force intended to signal a new landscape against Trump.\n\nHarris said when she was reelected she was going to work to sign important legislation on immigration and \"show Donald Trump what real leadership looks like.\"\n\nThe roughly 8,000-capacity basketball arena at Georgia State University was filled to its rafters with thousands of voters waving signs, dancing to the Harris campaign soundtrack and celebrating an atmosphere that would not have been possible just 10 days ago, with the party reeling over whether the 81-year-old Biden would remain in the race after a dismal performance magnified concerns about his age and abilities.\n\n\"This is like Barack Obama 2008 on steroids for me,\" said Mildred Hobson Doss, a 59-year-old who came downtown from suburban Lilburn. \"I would have voted for President Biden again. But we are ready.\"\n\nHarris is hoping the rally, which featured a performance by hip-hop star Megan Thee Stallion, will help affirm her campaign's momentum. The campaign argues that Harris' appeal to young people, working-age women and non-white voters has scrambled the dynamics in Georgia and other states that are demographically similar, from North Carolina to Nevada and Arizona.\n\n\"The energy is infectious,\" said Georgia Democratic Chairwoman Nikema Williams, a congresswoman from Atlanta. \"My phone has been blowing up. People want to be part of this movement.\"\n\nIn a strategy memo released after the president left the race, Harris campaign chair Jen O'Malley Dillon, who held the same role for Biden, reaffirmed the importance of winning Michigan, Wisconsin and Pennsylvania, a trio of industrial states that have formed the traditional Democratic blue wall.\n\nBut she also argued that the vice president's place atop the ticket \"opens up additional persuadable voters\" and described them as \"disproportionately Black, Latino and under 30\" in places like Georgia.\n\n\"This campaign is about freedom,\" said Georgia Sen. Raphael Warnock, who was there with his fellow Democratic Sen. Jon Ossoff. \"So the question is, do you want to be free? Or do you want to go back?\"\n\n\"When you show up, we win.\"\n\nRepublicans, who still control Georgia's state government, counter that Biden's lagging popularity and concern over higher consumer prices and immigration will transfer to Harris in the historically conservative state.\n\nBut they concede that the landscape suddenly looks much closer to 2020 - when Biden won by about 0.25 percentage points -- than when Trump was riding high after the Republican National Convention and surviving an assassination attempt.\n\n\"Trump was going to win Georgia. It was over,\" said Republican consultant Brian Robinson. \"The Democrats have a chance here for a reset.\"\n\nAnd Trump is not taking chances. Earlier Tuesday, the former president announced that he would come to Atlanta on Saturday for a rally in the same Georgia State arena.\n\nRobinson said Harris still has plenty of liabilities, including the progressive positions she took in her failed 2020 primary campaign and her various rhetorical stumbles. But he said Harris so far in this campaign has been \"in command,\" and if that continues, \"we have a new ballgame and she will be competitive in Georgia.\"\n\nTrump campaign spokesperson Karoline Leavitt dismissed Harris as \"just as weak, failed and incompetent as Joe Biden\" and said the vice president would have to explain her support of Biden administration policies that \"hurt working families in Georgia over the past four years.\"\n\nThe Harris campaign and Georgia Democratic officials have 24 offices across the state, including two added last weekend in metro Atlanta. Trump and the Republican National Committee opened their first Georgia offices only recently.\n\nDemocrats are betting that a combination of high turnout among traditional, core Democratic constituencies, as well as a strong showing in the suburbs and small pickups elsewhere, can be enough for Harris to carry Georgia.\n\nGeorgia Gov. Brian Kemp, a Republican, said in a recent interview that the best GOP campaigns can win comfortably in Georgia but bad efforts -- combined with strong Democratic campaigns -- lose. Kemp, for example, won reelection by 7.5 percentage points in 2022 over national Democratic star Stacey Abrams. Yet in the same election cycle, Georgians reelected Democratic Sen. Raphael Warnock over his Republican challenger Herschel Walker, who was endorsed by Trump.\n\nIn recent elections, Democrats have held wide advantages in the core of metro Atlanta, where Jayapal spoke. The party also performed well in Columbus and Savannah, as well as some rural, majority-Black counties. But Republicans dominated in other rural areas and small towns and cities -- where Trump has held multiple rallies in recent years.\n\nThe fast-growing, diversifying Atlanta suburbs and exurbs offer the most opportunity for swings, especially from GOP-leaning moderates disenchanted with Trump.\n\nFor Harris, that means depending on voters as varied as Michael Sleister, a white suburbanite, and Allen Smith, a Black man who lives not far from downtown Atlanta.\n\nSleister, who considers himself an independent, has lived in Forsyth County for 35 years. \"I've voted Republican many times in my life,\" he said, but not since the GOP took a rightward turn during President Barack Obama's administration.\n\n\"Now I see the Republican Party as representing a direct threat to my grandchildren,\" he said, adding that he sees Trump \"as just a horrible person.\"\n\nSmith is a 41-year-old Atlanta native who has become a first-time campaign volunteer since Harris became the likely nominee.\n\n\"I was driving when I heard the news about President Biden endorsing her, and I started pounding my fist -- I decided right then I would do whatever I could to help her get elected,\" Smith said.", "news/Politics", "label": "news/Politics", "wgt": 100}], "image": "https://assets.telegraphindia.com/telegraph/2024/Jul/1722041692_1720242560_kamala_ap_pti.jpg", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9774352", "eventUri": "eng-9774352", "location": null, "extractedDates": null, "sentiment": 0.1686274509803922, "wgt": 177, "relevance": 1}
{"uri": "8251624105", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "02:42:10", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T02:42:10Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T02:41:20Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6941176652908325, "url": "https://penncapital-star.com/election-2024/harris-challenges-trump-at-boisterous-georgia-state-rally-to-say-it-to-my-face-in-debate-dare/", "title": "Harris challenges Trump at boisterous Georgia State rally to 'say it to my face' in debate dare * Pennsylvania Capital-Star", "body": "Vice President Kamala Harris challenged former President Donald Trump to debate her Tuesday as a crowd at the Georgia State University Convocation Center. (Ross Williams/Georgia Recorder)\n\nVice President Kamala Harris spoke to a fired-up crowd Tuesday in Georgia where Democrats have been buoyed by her rise to the top of the ballot and what they see as a new opportunity to shut former President Donald Trump out of the White House.\n\n\"The path to the White House runs right through this state,\" Harris said to a packed Georgia State Convocation Center in downtown Atlanta. \"And you all helped us win in 2020 and we are going to do it again in 2024.\"\n\nThis was Harris' first visit to Georgia as the likely Democratic nominee after President Joe Biden's withdrawal upended the 2024 presidential race. But Harris has been a frequent visitor to Georgia as vice president, making Tuesday's rally her 15th stop here since being sworn in less than four years ago.\n\nThe shake-up at the top of the ballot has transformed a presidential race that was plagued with low voter enthusiasm, even dread for some.\n\nAnd the new energy was palpable Tuesday, with a performance from Megan Thee Stallion and warm-up speeches from a string of prominent Democrats and Atlanta rapper Quavo revving up the crowd ahead of Harris.\n\nSupporters filled the arena with deafening cheers and chants like \"not going back\" and \"too scared\" in reference to Trump backing out of a second presidential debate, but first against Harris. The spirited crowd at times drowned out the speakers. Harris walked out to rowdy applause and chants of \"Kamala.\"\n\nHarris taunted Trump for backing out of the debate schedule that he agreed to when Biden was still the expected Democratic nominee.\n\n\"Well, Donald, I do hope you'll reconsider to meet me on the debate stage,\" she said. \"Because as the saying goes, if you've got something to say, say it to my face.\"\n\nHarris campaign aides told reporters Monday that they are seeing measurable signs of enthusiasm in the surge of volunteers and donations, but they recognize that 2020's razor-thin victory in Georgia will be a challenge to repeat. Biden won Georgia by less than 12,000 votes, making him the first Democratic presidential candidate to win the state in three decades.\n\n\"Let's level set, friends, let's level set,\" Harris said to the boisterous crowd. \"We have a fight in front of us, and we are the underdogs in this race.\"\n\nThis crowd seemed eager for the challenge, and the opportunity to potentially elect a candidate whose presidency would make history was also electrifying the crowd.\n\n\"We will do the work of making Kamala Harris not only someone who breaks ties in the Senate but breaks barriers in the oval office,\" said Stacey Abrams, a former House minority leader who came close to becoming the nation's first Black woman governor back in 2018.\n\nBut the Harris campaign is also hoping moderate and disaffected Republicans will help deny Trump another term in the White House.\n\nFormer GOP Lt. Gov. Geoff Duncan, who has been a vocal critic of Trump since the aftermath of the 2020 election, was seen on the sidelines at Tuesday's rally. Duncan endorsed Biden earlier and has since backed Harris as a means for getting the Republican party to move on past Trump.\n\nDuncan said Tuesday that the party lines \"are blurred more than ever\" today.\n\n\"This is a historical event that's going to take place,\" Duncan said in an interview. \"I think there's an opportunity for this country to hit the reset button even. It means we have to vote for somebody we don't agree with a hundred percent of their policies.\"\n\nTrump answered Harris' Georgia stop by announcing one of his own set for this Saturday at the same downtown Atlanta venue. The GOP nominee will campaign with his running mate, Ohio U.S. Sen. J.D. Vance.\n\nFormer GOP Congressman Doug Collins said Georgia Republicans are mentally adjusting to Harris as the new rival. To Collins, the shake-up at the top of the ticket is about Democrats trying to regain ground after Biden's disastrous debate performance in Atlanta a month ago.\n\n\"She can't run from an administration record and that's what most people, especially people on the left, have forgotten,\" Collins said Tuesday.\n\nSure, Democrats are excited to have a candidate they believe can take on Trump, Collins said. But he said he thinks the media's portrayal of Harris' impact on the race is \"over the top.\"\n\nGeorgia Democrats, though, would disagree.\n\n\"I'm so excited I can't sleep at night,\" said Gloria Jenkins, an 82-year-old who chairs the Democratic Party of Georgia's senior caucus who is thrilled at the prospect of potentially helping to elect the first Black woman president.\n\nBefore Harris became the likely nominee, Jenkins acknowledged the lagging energy in Georgia. But she said that has changed and that her constantly low cell phone battery - drained from all the election chatter - is as good a barometer as any.\n\nFor Diahann Fulwider, Harris' rise has inspired her to vote in November after she decided she would sit this one out when her disappointment in Biden turned into dismay as she watched the president struggle through the CNN debate last month.\n\nFulwider, who is a member of the Alpha Kappa Alpha Sorority, Inc., called the response to Harris' presidential candidacy \"a movement.\" Harris is also a member of AKA.\n\n\"It reenergized the middle-class Black woman,\" Fulwilder said of Harris' presidential campaign.", "source": {"uri": "penncapital-star.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Pennsylvania Capital-Star"}, "authors": [], {"uri": "8251516928", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "00:22:08", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T00:22:08Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T00:21:17Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6941176652908325, "url": "https://www.pressherald.com/2024/07/30/at-boisterous-georgia-rally-harris-says-she-will-show-trump-what-real-leadership-looks-like/", "title": "At boisterous Georgia rally, Harris says she will show Trump 'what real leadership looks like'", "body": "Vice President Kamala Harris arrives at a campaign rally on Tuesday in Atlanta. The roughly 8,000-capacity basketball arena at Georgia State University was filled to its rafters. John Bazemore/Associated Press\n\nATLANTA -- Vice President Kamala Harris told a cheering, boisterous, packed arena on Tuesday that the next few months would be a serious fight and acknowledged the Democrats were right now the underdogs - but assured the crowd they would win in November.\n\n\"We have a fight in front of us,\" the likely nominee said. \"The momentum in this race is shifting. And there are signs Donald Trump is feeling it.\"\n\nLittle more than a week ago, Georgia appeared to be slipping out of the Democrats' reach: President Biden's campaign pledged to concentrate more on holding the Midwestern \"blue wall\" states and indicated they might be willing to forsake \"Sun Belt\" battlegrounds.\n\nBut now that Biden has bowed out of the race and Harris is the likely nominee, Democrats are expressing new hopes of an expanded electoral map and welcoming the vice president to the state that delivered Biden his narrowest victory margin in 2020 with a show of political force intended to signal a new landscape against Trump.\n\nHarris said when she was reelected she was going to work to sign important legislation on immigration and \"show Donald Trump what real leadership looks like.\"\n\nThe roughly 8,000-capacity basketball arena at Georgia State University was filled to its rafters with thousands of voters waving signs, dancing to the Harris campaign soundtrack and celebrating an atmosphere that would not have been possible just 10 days ago, with the party reeling over whether the 81-year-old Biden would remain in the race after a dismal performance magnified concerns about his age and abilities.\n\nAdvertisement\n\n\"This is like Barack Obama 2008 on steroids for me,\" said Mildred Hobson Doss, a 59-year-old who came downtown from suburban Lilburn. \"I would have voted for President Biden again. But we are ready.\"\n\nHarris is hoping the rally, which featured a performance by hip-hop star Megan Thee Stallion, will help affirm her campaign's momentum. The campaign argues that Harris' appeal to young people, working-age women and non-white voters has scrambled the dynamics in Georgia and other states that are demographically similar, from North Carolina to Nevada and Arizona.\n\n\"The energy is infectious,\" said Georgia Democratic Chairwoman Nikema Williams, a congresswoman from Atlanta. \"My phone has been blowing up. People want to be part of this movement.\"\n\nIn a strategy memo released after the president left the race, Harris campaign chair Jen O'Malley Dillon, who held the same role for Biden, reaffirmed the importance of winning Michigan, Wisconsin and Pennsylvania, a trio of industrial states that have formed the traditional Democratic blue wall.\n\nBut she also argued that the vice president's place atop the ticket \"opens up additional persuadable voters\" and described them as \"disproportionately Black, Latino and under 30\" in places like Georgia.\n\n\"This campaign is about freedom,\" said Georgia Sen. Raphael Warnock, who was there with his fellow Democratic Sen. Jon Ossoff. \"So the question is, do you want to be free? Or do you want to go back? When you show up, we win.\"\n\nAdvertisement\n\nRepublicans, who still control Georgia's state government, counter that Biden's lagging popularity and concern over higher consumer prices and immigration will transfer to Harris in the historically conservative state.\n\nBut they concede that the landscape suddenly looks much closer to 2020 - when Biden won by about 0.25 percentage points - than when Trump was riding high after the Republican National Convention and surviving an assassination attempt.\n\n\"Trump was going to win Georgia. It was over,\" said Republican consultant Brian Robinson. \"The Democrats have a chance here for a reset.\"\n\nAnd Trump is not taking chances. Earlier Tuesday, the former president announced that he would come to Atlanta on Saturday for a rally in the same Georgia State arena.\n\nRobinson said Harris still has plenty of liabilities, including the progressive positions she took in her failed 2020 primary campaign and her various rhetorical stumbles. But he said Harris so far in this campaign has been \"in command,\" and if that continues, \"we have a new ballgame and she will be competitive in Georgia.\"\n\nTrump campaign spokesperson Karoline Leavitt dismissed Harris as \"just as weak, failed and incompetent as Joe Biden\" and said the vice president would have to explain her support of Biden administration policies that \"hurt working families in Georgia over the past four years.\"\n\nAdvertisement\n\nThe Harris campaign and Georgia Democratic officials have 24 offices across the state, including two added last weekend in metro Atlanta. Trump and the Republican National Committee opened their first Georgia offices only recently.\n\nDemocrats are betting that a combination of high turnout among traditional, core Democratic constituencies, as well as a strong showing in the suburbs and small pickups elsewhere, can be enough for Harris to carry Georgia.\n\nGeorgia Gov. Brian Kemp, a Republican, said in a recent interview that the best GOP campaigns can win comfortably in Georgia but bad efforts - combined with strong Democratic campaigns - lose. Kemp, for example, won reelection by 7.5 percentage points in 2022 over national Democratic star Stacey Abrams. Yet in the same election cycle, Georgians reelected Democratic Sen. Raphael Warnock over his Republican challenger Herschel Walker, who was endorsed by Trump.\n\nThe fast-growing, diversifying Atlanta suburbs and exurbs offer the most opportunity for swings, especially from GOP-leaning moderates disenchanted with Trump.\n\nFor Harris, that means depending on voters as varied as Michael Sleister, a white suburbanite, and Allen Smith, a Black man who lives not far from downtown Atlanta.\n\nSleister, who considers himself an independent, has lived in Forsyth County for 35 years. \"I've voted Republican many times in my life,\" he said, but not since the GOP took a rightward turn during President Barack Obama's administration.\n\n\"Now I see the Republican Party as representing a direct threat to my grandchildren,\" he said, adding that he sees Trump \"as just a horrible person.\"\n\nSmith is a 41-year-old Atlanta native who has become a first-time campaign volunteer since Harris became the likely nominee.\n\n\"I was driving when I heard the news about President Biden endorsing her, and I started pounding my fist - I decided right then I would do whatever I could to help her get elected,\" Smith said.\n\nCopy the Story Link\n\nSend questions/comments to the editors.\n\n\" Previous\n\nInvestigation finds at least 973 Native American children died in U.S. government boarding schools filed under: election 2024, kamala harris {"uri": "8251526774", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "00:34:24", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T00:34:24Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T00:33:38Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6901960968971252, "url": "https://www.staradvertiser.com/2024/07/30/breaking-news/harris-draws-crowds-in-georgia-with-megan-thee-stallion/", "title": "Harris draws crowds in Georgia with Megan Thee Stallion | Honolulu Star-Advertiser", "body": "Vice President Kamala Harris visits Paschal's, a historic Black-owned restaurant in Atlanta, Ga.\n\nATLANTA >> Vice President Kamala Harris tapped into the popularity of rappers Megan Thee Stallion and Quavo at a spirited Atlanta rally that highlighted the new energy she has brought to November's election.\n\nIn her first trip to Georgia as a presidential candidate on Tuesday, Harris pledged Democrats will win the state, after Biden dropped out of the race and endorsed his one-time running mate. The momentum in this race is shifting, and \"Donald Trump is feeling it,\" she said.\n\nWith less than 100 days left in one of the least predictable campaign seasons in recent history, Democrats are redrawing their map to victory, hoping the prospect of the first Black and Asian woman president can motivate Democrats to the polls.\n\n\"We are not going back,\" Harris said to cheers and chants of about 10,000 attendees.\n\nMegan Thee Stallion, whose album \"Megan\" recently launched at No. 1 on Billboard's Top R&B/Hip-Hop albums chart, performed in a blue pantsuit and tie, the color associated with Harris' Democratic Party.\n\nShe joins a host of musicians who have recently come out in support of Harris' bid to become the Democratic presidential nominee in the Nov. 5 election.\n\nGeorgia Sen. Jon Ossoff, a Democrat, said on MSNBC over the weekend that Harris' entry into the race \"has put Georgia in play\" for Democrats and predicted she will win.\n\nSwing states like Georgia, which Democrats barely won in a hard-fought battle in 2020, are fiercely contested because they can lean either to Republicans or Democrats and play a decisive role in presidential elections.\n\nFiveThirtyEight, the poll aggregation site, shows Republican Donald Trump leading Harris by between one and five percentage points in surveys taken after Harris became the likely Democratic candidate.\n\nPresident Joe Biden ended his reelection bid on July 22 and endorsed Harris for the Nov. 5 vote against Trump. Since then, Harris' election campaign has raised $200 million, signed up 170,000 new volunteers and she has significantly outperformed Biden in recent polling among young people, Black voters and Hispanic voters.\n\nA New York Times/Siena College national poll published Thursday found Harris has narrowed a sizable Trump lead, while Trump had a two percentage point lead in a Wall Street Journal poll published on Friday. A Reuters/Ipsos poll published July 23 showed a two-point lead for Harris.\n\nBiden's campaign saw a narrowing path to victory with the \"Sun Belt states,\" including Georgia, Arizona and Nevada, as unlikely wins. Georgia backed Biden by 0.2 percentage points, just under 12,000 votes in 2020, and Trump by around 5 percentage points in 2016.\n\nAndy Beshear, the twice-elected Democratic governor of deep-red Kentucky, visited Georgia over the weekend to campaign for Harris in the Republican stronghold of Forsyth County.\n\nThe Harris campaign is vetting him along with Sen. Mark Kelly of Arizona, Governor Josh Shapiro of Pennsylvania and Governor Tim Walz of Minnesota as possible vice presidential candidates. A decision is expected by Aug. 7.\n\nHarris is leaning into her resume as a former district attorney and California attorney general, seeking to draw a contrast with Trump who is the first former president to be convicted of felony crimes.\n\nTrump and 14 co-defendants are accused of racketeering and other charges for their role in attempting to overturn Biden's narrow win in Georgia.", "source": {"uri": "staradvertiser.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Honolulu Star Advertiser"}, "authors": [{"uri": "reuters@staradvertiser.com", "name": "Reuters", "type": "author", "isAgency": {"uri": "8251625627", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "02:45:57", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T02:45:57Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T02:43:24Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6901960968971252, "url": "https://www.dailymaverick.co.za/article/2024-07-31-kamala-harris-draws-crowds-in-georgia-with-megan-thee-stallion-quavo/", "title": "Kamala Harris draws crowds in Georgia with Megan Thee Stallion, Quavo", "body": "ATLANTA, July 30 (Reuters) - U.S. Vice President Kamala Harris joined rappers Megan Thee Stallion and Quavo at a spirited Atlanta rally that highlighted the new energy she has brought to November's election.\n\nIn her first trip to Georgia as a presidential candidate on Tuesday, Harris pledged Democrats will win a state the party had written off, and taunted Republican Donald Trump for backing out of a debate with her.\n\nThe momentum in this race is shifting, and \"Donald Trump is feeling it,\" Harris said, as the crowd of about 10,000 cheered and shouted her nascent campaign slogan \"We are not going back.\"\n\nWith less than 100 days left in one of the least predictable campaign seasons in recent history, Democrats are redrawing their map to victory, hoping the prospect of the first Black and Asian woman president can motivate Democrats to the polls.\n\nHarris' election campaign, hastily put together after President Joe Biden ended his re-election bid on July 22, has raised $200 million, and signed up 170,000 new volunteers.\n\nIn Atlanta, Harris embraced some Biden policy priorities, promising, \"On Day One I will take on price gouging and bring down costs.\" She said she would ban more hidden banking fees, take on corporate landlords and \"cap unfair rent increases\".\n\nShe also addressed immigration on the southern border, a top issue for Republican voters after the arrests of migrants crossing illegally reached a high during the Biden administration. Harris' role in trying to tamp down migration has drawn Republican criticism.\n\nTrump has been \"talking a big game about securing the border,\" but he does not walk the walk, Harris said. Trump pushed Republicans to tank a bill that would have funded more border security measures, she added, referring to a bill that failed in February.\n\nMegan Thee Stallion, whose album \"Megan\" recently launched at No. 1 on Billboard's Top R&B/Hip-Hop albums chart, performed before Harris spoke while wearing a blue pantsuit and tie, the color associated with Harris' Democratic Party. \"Lets get this done hotties. Hotties for Harris,\" she told the crowd.\n\nGeorgia Senator Jon Ossoff, a Democrat, said on MSNBC over the weekend that Harris' entry into the race \"has put Georgia in play\" for Democrats and predicted she will win.\n\nSwing states like Georgia, which Democrats barely won in 2020, are fiercely contested because they can lean either to Republicans or Democrats and play a decisive role in presidential elections.\n\nFiveThirtyEight, the poll aggregation site, shows Republican Donald Trump leading Harris by between one and five percentage points in surveys taken after Harris became the likely Democratic candidate.\n\nSince Biden ended his reelection bid for the Nov. 5 vote against Trump, Harris has significantly outperformed him in recent polling among young people, Black voters and Hispanic voters.\n\nAfter Harris's speech, she appeared on a Zoom call with supporters, telling them \"this is a sprint\" and asking them to volunteer. Her campaign's battleground director Dan Kanninen said the team was looking at the \"Blue wall\" states of Pennsylvania, Wisconsin and Michigan to win the election, but was also hopeful about the \"Sun Belt.\"\n\nA New York Times/Siena College national poll published on Thursday found Harris has narrowed a sizable Trump lead, while Trump had a two percentage point lead in a Wall Street Journal poll published on Friday. A Reuters/Ipsos poll published on Tuesday showed Harris with a one point lead over Trump, down from two points in a July 23 poll.\n\nBiden's campaign saw a narrowing path to victory with the \"Sun Belt states,\" including Georgia, Arizona and Nevada, as unlikely wins. Georgia backed Biden by 0.2 percentage points, just under 12,000 votes in 2020, and Trump by around 5 percentage points in 2016.\n\nAndy Beshear, the twice-elected Democratic governor of deep-red Kentucky, visited Georgia over the weekend to campaign for Harris in the Republican stronghold of Forsyth County.\n\nThe Harris campaign is vetting him along with Senator Mark Kelly of Arizona, Governor Josh Shapiro of Pennsylvania and Governor Tim Walz of Minnesota as possible vice presidential candidates. A decision is expected by Aug. 7.\n\nHarris is leaning into her resume as a former district attorney and California attorney general, seeking to draw a contrast with Trump who is the first former president to be convicted of felony crimes.\n\nTrump and 14 co-defendants are accused of racketeering and other charges for their role in attempting to overturn Biden's narrow win in Georgia.\n\n(Reporting by Nandita Bose in Washington; Additional reporting by Trevor Hunnicutt; Editing by Heather Timmons, Stephen Coates, Deepa Babington, Chris Reese and Christian Schmollinger)", {"uri": "8251527417", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "00:36:23", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T00:36:23Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T00:34:40Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.686274528503418, "url": "https://www.fox41yakima.com/at-boisterous-georgia-rally-harris-says-she-will-show-trump-what-real-leadership-looks-like/", "title": "At boisterous Georgia rally, Harris says she will show Trump 'what real leadership looks like' | Fox 11 Tri Cities Fox 41 Yakima", "body": "ATLANTA (AP) -- Vice President Kamala Harris told a cheering, boisterous, packed arena on Tuesday that the next few months would be a serious fight and acknowledged the Democrats were right now the underdogs -- but assured the crowd they would win in November.\n\n\"We have a fight in front of us,\" the likely nominee said. \"The momentum in this race is shifting. And there are signs Donald Trump is feeling it.\"\n\nLittle more than a week ago, Georgia appeared to be slipping out of the Democrats' reach: President Joe Biden's campaign pledged to concentrate more on holding the Midwestern \"blue wall\" states and indicated they might be willing to forsake \"Sun Belt\" battlegrounds.\n\nBut now that Biden has bowed out of the race and Harris is the likely nominee, Democrats are expressing new hopes of an expanded electoral map and welcoming the vice president to the state that delivered Biden his narrowest victory margin in 2020 with a show of political force intended to signal a new landscape against Trump.\n\nHarris said when she was reelected she was going to work to sign important legislation on immigration and \"show Donald Trump what real leadership looks like.\"\n\nThe roughly 8,000-capacity basketball arena at Georgia State University was filled to its rafters with thousands of voters waving signs, dancing to the Harris campaign soundtrack and celebrating an atmosphere that would not have been possible just 10 days ago, with the party reeling over whether the 81-year-old Biden would remain in the race after a dismal performance magnified concerns about his age and abilities.\n\n\"This is like Barack Obama 2008 on steroids for me,\" said Mildred Hobson Doss, a 59-year-old who came downtown from suburban Lilburn. \"I would have voted for President Biden again. But we are ready.\"\n\nHarris is hoping the rally, which featured a performance by hip-hop star Megan Thee Stallion, will help affirm her campaign's momentum. The campaign argues that Harris' appeal to young people, working-age women and non-white voters has scrambled the dynamics in Georgia and other states that are demographically similar, from North Carolina to Nevada and Arizona.\n\n\"The energy is infectious,\" said Georgia Democratic Chairwoman Nikema Williams, a congresswoman from Atlanta. \"My phone has been blowing up. People want to be part of this movement.\"\n\nIn a strategy memo released after the president left the race, Harris campaign chair Jen O'Malley Dillon, who held the same role for Biden, reaffirmed the importance of winning Michigan, Wisconsin and Pennsylvania, a trio of industrial states that have formed the traditional Democratic blue wall.\n\nBut she also argued that the vice president's place atop the ticket \"opens up additional persuadable voters\" and described them as \"disproportionately Black, Latino and under 30\" in places like Georgia.\n\n\"This campaign is about freedom,\" said Georgia Sen. Raphael Warnock, who was there with his fellow Democratic Sen. Jon Ossoff. \"So the question is, do you want to be free? Or do you want to go back?\"\n\n\"When you show up, we win.\"\n\nRepublicans, who still control Georgia's state government, counter that Biden's lagging popularity and concern over higher consumer prices and immigration will transfer to Harris in the historically conservative state.\n\nBut they concede that the landscape suddenly looks much closer to 2020 - when Biden won by about 0.25 percentage points -- than when Trump was riding high after the Republican National Convention and surviving an assassination attempt.\n\n\"Trump was going to win Georgia. It was over,\" said Republican consultant Brian Robinson. \"The Democrats have a chance here for a reset.\"\n\nAnd Trump is not taking chances. Earlier Tuesday, the former president announced that he would come to Atlanta on Saturday for a rally in the same Georgia State arena.\n\nRobinson said Harris still has plenty of liabilities, including the progressive positions she took in her failed 2020 primary campaign and her various rhetorical stumbles. But he said Harris so far in this campaign has been \"in command,\" and if that continues, \"we have a new ballgame and she will be competitive in Georgia.\"\n\nTrump campaign spokesperson Karoline Leavitt dismissed Harris as \"just as weak, failed and incompetent as Joe Biden\" and said the vice president would have to explain her support of Biden administration policies that \"hurt working families in Georgia over the past four years.\"\n\nThe Harris campaign and Georgia Democratic officials have 24 offices across the state, including two added last weekend in metro Atlanta. Trump and the Republican National Committee opened their first Georgia offices only recently.\n\nDemocrats are betting that a combination of high turnout among traditional, core Democratic constituencies, as well as a strong showing in the suburbs and small pickups elsewhere, can be enough for Harris to carry Georgia.\n\nGeorgia Gov. Brian Kemp, a Republican, said in a recent interview that the best GOP campaigns can win comfortably in Georgia but bad efforts -- combined with strong Democratic campaigns -- lose. Kemp, for example, won reelection by 7.5 percentage points in 2022 over national Democratic star Stacey Abrams. Yet in the same election cycle, Georgians reelected Democratic Sen. Raphael Warnock over his Republican challenger Herschel Walker, who was endorsed by Trump.\n\nIn recent elections, Democrats have held wide advantages in the core of metro Atlanta, where Jayapal spoke. The party also performed well in Columbus and Savannah, as well as some rural, majority-Black counties. But Republicans dominated in other rural areas and small towns and cities -- where Trump has held multiple rallies in recent years.\n\nThe fast-growing, diversifying Atlanta suburbs and exurbs offer the most opportunity for swings, especially from GOP-leaning moderates disenchanted with Trump.\n\nFor Harris, that means depending on voters as varied as Michael Sleister, a white suburbanite, and Allen Smith, a Black man who lives not far from downtown Atlanta.\n\nSleister, who considers himself an independent, has lived in Forsyth County for 35 years. \"I've voted Republican many times in my life,\" he said, but not since the GOP took a rightward turn during President Barack Obama's administration.\n\n\"Now I see the Republican Party as representing a direct threat to my grandchildren,\" he said, adding that he sees Trump \"as just a horrible person.\"\n\nSmith is a 41-year-old Atlanta native who has become a first-time campaign volunteer since Harris became the likely nominee.\n\n\"I was driving when I heard the news about President Biden endorsing her, and I started pounding my fist -- I decided right then I would do whatever I could to help her get elected,\" Smith said.\n\nFollow the AP's coverage of the 2024 election at https://apnews.com/hub/election-2024.\n\nFOX41 Yakima\u00a9FOX11 TriCities\u00a9", "source": {"uri": "fox41yakima.com", "dataType": "news", "https://www.fox41yakima.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/02/Fox41-Local-News-2.jpg", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9774352", "eventUri": "eng-9774352", "location": {"type": "place", "label": {"uri": "2024-07-438866411", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "23:51:35", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T23:51:35Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T23:39:21Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.686274528503418, "url": "https://www.register-herald.com/news/nation_world/at-boisterous-georgia-rally-harris-says-she-will-show-trump-what-real-leadership-looks-like/article_08d4d043-9447-5b38-80bd-a1acf68f09c5.html", "title": "At boisterous Georgia rally, Harris says she will show Trump 'what real leadership looks like'", "body": "ATLANTA (AP) -- Vice President Kamala Harris told a cheering, boisterous, packed arena on Tuesday that the next few months would be a serious fight and acknowledged the Democrats were right now the underdogs -- but assured the crowd they would win in November.\n\n\"We have a fight in front of us,\" the likely nominee said. \"The momentum in this race is shifting. And there are signs Donald Trump is feeling it.\"\n\nLittle more than a week ago, Georgia appeared to be slipping out of the Democrats' reach: President Joe Biden's campaign pledged to concentrate more on holding the Midwestern \"blue wall\" states and indicated they might be willing to forsake \"Sun Belt\" battlegrounds.\n\nBut now that Biden has bowed out of the race and Harris is the likely nominee, Democrats are expressing new hopes of an expanded electoral map and welcoming the vice president to the state that delivered Biden his narrowest victory margin in 2020 with a show of political force intended to signal a new landscape against Trump.\n\nHarris said when she was reelected she was going to work to sign important legislation on immigration and \"show Donald Trump what real leadership looks like.\"\n\nThe roughly 8,000-capacity basketball arena at Georgia State University was filled to its rafters with thousands of voters waving signs, dancing to the Harris campaign soundtrack and celebrating an atmosphere that would not have been possible just 10 days ago, with the party reeling over whether the 81-year-old Biden would remain in the race after a dismal performance magnified concerns about his age and abilities.\n\n\"This is like Barack Obama 2008 on steroids for me,\" said Mildred Hobson Doss, a 59-year-old who came downtown from suburban Lilburn. \"I would have voted for President Biden again. But we are ready.\"\n\nHarris is hoping the rally, which featured a performance by hip-hop star Megan Thee Stallion, will help affirm her campaign's momentum. The campaign argues that Harris' appeal to young people, working-age women and non-white voters has scrambled the dynamics in Georgia and other states that are demographically similar, from North Carolina to Nevada and Arizona.\n\n\"The energy is infectious,\" said Georgia Democratic Chairwoman Nikema Williams, a congresswoman from Atlanta. \"My phone has been blowing up. People want to be part of this movement.\"\n\nIn a strategy memo released after the president left the race, Harris campaign chair Jen O'Malley Dillon, who held the same role for Biden, reaffirmed the importance of winning Michigan, Wisconsin and Pennsylvania, a trio of industrial states that have formed the traditional Democratic blue wall.\n\nBut she also argued that the vice president's place atop the ticket \"opens up additional persuadable voters\" and described them as \"disproportionately Black, Latino and under 30\" in places like Georgia.\n\n\"This campaign is about freedom,\" said Georgia Sen. Raphael Warnock, who was there with his fellow Democratic Sen. Jon Ossoff. \"So the question is, do you want to be free? Or do you want to go back?\"\n\n\"When you show up, we win.\"\n\nRepublicans, who still control Georgia's state government, counter that Biden's lagging popularity and concern over higher consumer prices and immigration will transfer to Harris in the historically conservative state.\n\nBut they concede that the landscape suddenly looks much closer to 2020 - when Biden won by about 0.25 percentage points -- than when Trump was riding high after the Republican National Convention and surviving an assassination attempt.\n\n\"Trump was going to win Georgia. It was over,\" said Republican consultant Brian Robinson. \"The Democrats have a chance here for a reset.\"\n\nAnd Trump is not taking chances. Earlier Tuesday, the former president announced that he would come to Atlanta on Saturday for a rally in the same Georgia State arena.\n\nRobinson said Harris still has plenty of liabilities, including the progressive positions she took in her failed 2020 primary campaign and her various rhetorical stumbles. But he said Harris so far in this campaign has been \"in command,\" and if that continues, \"we have a new ballgame and she will be competitive in Georgia.\"\n\nTrump campaign spokesperson Karoline Leavitt dismissed Harris as \"just as weak, failed and incompetent as Joe Biden\" and said the vice president would have to explain her support of Biden administration policies that \"hurt working families in Georgia over the past four years.\"\n\nThe Harris campaign and Georgia Democratic officials have 24 offices across the state, including two added last weekend in metro Atlanta. Trump and the Republican National Committee opened their first Georgia offices only recently.\n\nDemocrats are betting that a combination of high turnout among traditional, core Democratic constituencies, as well as a strong showing in the suburbs and small pickups elsewhere, can be enough for Harris to carry Georgia.\n\nGeorgia Gov. Brian Kemp, a Republican, said in a recent interview that the best GOP campaigns can win comfortably in Georgia but bad efforts -- combined with strong Democratic campaigns -- lose. Kemp, for example, won reelection by 7.5 percentage points in 2022 over national Democratic star Stacey Abrams. Yet in the same election cycle, Georgians reelected Democratic Sen. Raphael Warnock over his Republican challenger Herschel Walker, who was endorsed by Trump.\n\nIn recent elections, Democrats have held wide advantages in the core of metro Atlanta, where Jayapal spoke. The party also performed well in Columbus and Savannah, as well as some rural, majority-Black counties. But Republicans dominated in other rural areas and small towns and cities -- where Trump has held multiple rallies in recent years.\n\nThe fast-growing, diversifying Atlanta suburbs and exurbs offer the most opportunity for swings, especially from GOP-leaning moderates disenchanted with Trump.\n\nFor Harris, that means depending on voters as varied as Michael Sleister, a white suburbanite, and Allen Smith, a Black man who lives not far from downtown Atlanta.\n\nSleister, who considers himself an independent, has lived in Forsyth County for 35 years. \"I've voted Republican many times in my life,\" he said, but not since the GOP took a rightward turn during President Barack Obama's administration.\n\n\"Now I see the Republican Party as representing a direct threat to my grandchildren,\" he said, adding that he sees Trump \"as just a horrible person.\"\n\nSmith is a 41-year-old Atlanta native who has become a first-time campaign volunteer since Harris became the likely nominee.\n\n\"I was driving when I heard the news about President Biden endorsing her, and I started pounding my fist -- I decided right then I would do whatever I could to help her get elected,\" Smith said.\n\nFollow the AP's coverage of the 2024 election at https://apnews.com/hub/election-2024.", "source": {"uri": "register-herald.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Beckley Register-Herald"},
