{"uri": "8251574036", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "01:37:57", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T01:37:57Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T01:37:08Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6235294342041016, "url": "https://www.newsweek.com/kamala-harris-georgia-rally-key-takeaways-1932379", "title": "Kamala Harris' Georgia rally key takeaways", "body": "Vice President Kamala Harris on Tuesday rallied thousands of supporters during her first campaign stop in Georgia since launching her bid for the presidency.\n\nDemocrats have enjoyed a new momentum behind the vice president since she entered the 2024 race on July 21. Polling data, while limited, shows Harris starting to close the gap on former President Donald Trump across national polling. In the key battleground state of Georgia, Harris is tied with Trump, according to a recent poll released by Bloomberg News and Morning Consult.\n\nOrganizers of Tuesday's rally, held at the Georgia State University Convocation Center in Atlanta, told The New York Times that around 10,000 people attended the event, which included a performance by rapper Megan Thee Stallion. According to the stadium's website, the Convocation Center has seating for up to 8,000 guests.\n\nEarly into her roughly 20-minute speech, Harris repeated her line about knowing Trump's \"type,\" from her days as a prosecutor, again highlighting the former president's plethora of legal challenges and 34 felony convictions in Manhattan. Her supporters were also heard chanting, \"Lock him up!\" a play on the \"Lock her up!\" chant that Trump supporters hurled at former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton in the 2016 election.\n\nNewsweek reached out to Trump's campaign on Tuesday for comment on Harris' rally.\n\nBelow are a few key takeaways from Harris' rally on Tuesday:\n\nThe vice president threw another jab at Trump for backing out of his agreement to participate in the September 10 presidential debate that will be hosted by ABC News.\n\n\"So the momentum in this race is shifting, and there are signs that Donald Trump is feeling it,\" Harris said from the podium.\n\n\"Last week, you may have seen, [Trump] pulled out of the debate in September that he previously agreed to,\" Harris continued. \"Here's the funny thing about that. He won't debate, but he and his running mate sure seem to have a lot to say about me.\"\n\n\"Well, Donald, I do hope you'll reconsider to meet me on the debate stage,\" she added. \"Because as the saying goes, if you got something to say, say it to my face.\"\n\nTrump originally accepted ABC News' invitation to debate while President Joe Biden was still in the race as the Democrats' presumptive nominee. Since Harris announced her campaign, however, the former president has come up with several reasons why he no longer wants to participate, including saying that he thinks the network will not be impartial while moderating.\n\nHarris campaign spokesperson Ammar Moussa released a statement Monday evening, saying Trump was \"dodging\" questions about participating in the September 10 debate because \"he's scared he'll have to defend his running mate's weird attacks on women, or his own calls to end elections in America in a debate against the vice president.\" Trump picked Ohio Senator JD Vance as his running mate.\n\nHarris continued to build on her campaign's momentum by inviting Stallion, a Grammy Award-winning artist, to perform at Tuesday's rally before the vice president addressed supporters. Harris has been backed by a long list of celebrities since entering the 2024 race.\n\nRapper and Atlanta native Quavo also spoke before Harris took the stage and encouraged supporters to get out and vote. He also talked about his experience fighting to tackle gun violence with the Biden administration. His nephew Takeoff, former member of the Migos group that Quavo heads, was fatally shot in 2022.\n\n\"What's only right in the birthplace of the culture is also the same place to launch the first African American woman to run for president,\" Quavo said to a cheering crowd Tuesday.\n\nHarris was also joined by Georgia Senators Jon Ossoff and Raphael Warnock, both Democrats.\n\nStallion and Quavo's appearances underscore the Democratic Party's shift since Harris launched her campaign. The vice president's embrace of public figures and online trends is likely an effort to garner Gen Z voters' support in November.\n\nThe vice president also took on Trump's attacks regarding her record on immigration and promised to sign the bipartisan border security bill into law that was struck down in the Senate in the spring.\n\n\"Donald Trump has been talking a big game about securing our border, but he does not walk the walk,\" Harris said Tuesday.\n\n\"Our administration worked on the most significant border security bill in decades,\" she continued. \"Some of the most conservative Republicans in Washington, D.C., supported the bill ... It was all set to pass, but at the last minute, Trump directed his allies in the Senate to vote it down.\n\n\"He tanked the bipartisan deal because he thought it would help him win an election. Which goes to show, Donald Trump does not care about border security. He only cares about himself.\"\n\nAfter the border bill -- drafted by GOP Senator James Lankford of Oklahoma, independent Senator Kyrsten Sinema of Arizona and Democratic Senator Chris Murphy of Connecticut -- was presented to lawmakers in February, Trump described it as \"a great gift to the Democrats, and a Death Wish for The Republican Party\" in a post to his Truth Social account. Republicans have denied that the border bill was struck down by lawmakers due to Trump's criticism.\n\nTrump has also tried to capitalize on the immense pressure the Biden administration has faced over its handling of the U.S. southern border in his attacks on Harris, which he describes as the president's \"border czar.\" The vice president's campaign has responded by describing Trump's border policy as \"xenophobic.\"", "source": {"uri": "newsweek.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Newsweek"}, "authors": [{"uri": "kaitlin_lewis@newsweek.com", "name": "Kaitlin Lewis", "type": "author", The rapper confirmed on Instagram she would be at the event. Sens. Jon Ossoff and Raphael Warnock, Mayor Andre Dickens, Rep. Nikema Williams and former gubernatorial candidate Stacey Abrams will also join Harris, according to her campaign.\n\nHarris' campaign sees a win in Georgia, a battleground state, as one of her pathways to winning the 2024 election.\n\nMr. Biden very narrowly won the state against former President Donald Trump four years ago -- a rare victory in a state that hadn't backed a Democrat for president in nearly three decades. It was Mr. Biden's disastrous debate performance in Atlanta against Trump in June that ultimately led to the end of his reelection campaign.\n\nHarris is expected to announce her running mate by Aug. 7, the current deadline to obtain ballot access in Ohio, which requires nominees be certified at least 90 days before Election Day. Ohio lawmakers changed the deadline to Sept. 1, but the new law doesn't take effect until then, prompting Democrats to formalize their nominee before the convention in Chicago on Aug. 19 out of an abundance of caution.\n\nHarris said earlier Tuesday she has \"not yet\" made a decision about her running mate.\n\nHarris and the yet-to-be-named vice presidential candidate will campaign together in battleground states next week, sources familiar with the plans told CBS News.\n\nTrump and his running mate, Sen. JD Vance of Ohio, are scheduled to campaign in Atlanta on Saturday.\n\nCaitlin Yilek is a politics reporter at CBSNews.com, based in Washington, D.C. {"uri": "8252302017", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "11:01:49", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T11:01:49Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T11:00:49Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6235294342041016, "url": "https://theglobalherald.com/news/kamala-harris-calls-out-donald-trump-to-debate-amid-georgia-rally/", "title": "Kamala Harris Calls Out Donald Trump to Debate Amid Georgia Rally - The Global Herald", "body": "Kamala Harris, the Vice President of the United States, launched her presidential campaign in Georgia, a state considered pivotal in the upcoming election. During her rally in Atlanta, she directly challenged her Republican contender, Donald Trump, to engage her in a debate.\n\nThe rally attracted approximately 10,000 attendees and featured performances by renowned artists such as Megan Thee Stallion and Quavo. Additionally, Democratic Senator Raphael Warnock also made an appearance to rally support.\n\nRecent developments have altered the outlook for Democrats regarding Georgia, which once seemed difficult to win. Experts suggest that with a new candidate atop the ticket and renewed enthusiasm, the situation could shift dramatically.\n\nHarris stepped in as the presumed Democratic leader after President Biden withdrew from the race. \"It has been a reset button in so many ways,\" remarked Amy Morton, head of the consulting group Southern Majority. She noted that this change has significantly reshaped Georgia's electoral landscape.\n\nAs she addressed the enthusiastic crowd, Harris emphasized the changing dynamics of the race, asserting that her \"people-powered\" campaign, although underestimated, is gaining traction. She referenced Biden's victory in 2020, indicating a viable path for Democrats in Georgia.\n\nHarris noted, \"I am very clear the path to the White House runs right through this state.\"\n\nHarris shifted focus to the presidential debate scheduled for September, calling on Trump to engage directly. \"Donald, I do hope you'll reconsider to meet me on the debate stage because, as the saying goes, if you got something to say, say it to my face,\" she declared, highlighting her willingness to confront her opponent directly.\n\nGeorgia's significance in national elections is underscored by its status as a swing state, capable of swinging either red or blue. Trump and Harris will both be campaigning in Atlanta, indicating the importance of solidifying their bases in this crucial state. Harris's presence has reportedly generated increased enthusiasm among voters, with Congressman Hank Jackson noting that \"an explosion of enthusiasm has been unleashed\" since her nomination.\n\nGeorgia Democrats rely heavily on high turnout from Black voters, a demographic that is particularly significant in the region. Recent polling suggests Harris has narrowed the gap with Trump, leading by a slight margin among registered voters nationally.\n\nUniversity of Georgia Professor Charles Bullock pointed out that the state's status is now on Harris's \"watch list,\" highlighting her numerous visits aimed at energizing the electorate.\n\nDespite the support for Trump, who retains a strong backing in Georgia, Harris seeks to broaden her appeal. Bullock indicated that Harris could potentially attract moderate Republicans who may be dissatisfied with Trump's conduct. This could be critical as she aims for a broader coalition, seeking engagement from key demographics ahead of the election.\n\nWhile addressing concerns about immigration, a prominent issue among Georgia voters, Harris pledged to revive a border security bill stalled by Trump during his time in office.\n\nAs the campaign progresses, the interplay between enthusiasm for Harris and the existing Trump support will be pivotal in determining the electoral landscape in Georgia, a critical battleground for both parties.", "source": {"uri": "theglobalherald.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The {"uri": "8251497682", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "00:00:24", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T00:00:24Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T23:59:29Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6196078658103943, "url": "https://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-13690727/kamala-harris-donald-trump-georgia-rally-megan-thee-stallion.html", "title": "Kamala Harris slams Trump on border, dares him to debate her", "body": "By Emily Goodin, Senior White House Correspondent In Atlanta\n\nKamala Harris repeatedly attacked Donald Trump at her biggest campaign rally to date, accusing him failing to secure the border and dared him to debate her in September.\n\nTrump and Republicans have repeatedly attacked Harris on the Biden's border policy, calling her the administration's 'border czar.'\n\nBut she hit back on Tuesday night.\n\n'I was the attorney general of a border state. In that job I walked underground tunnels on that border,' she said. 'I went after drug cartels, human traffickers ... I prosecuted them in case after case and I won. Donald Trump on the other hand talked a big game about securing our border but he's not walking the talk. Or as my friend Quavo would say, he's not walking it like he talks it.'\n\nShe noted Trump 'tanked' the bipartisan deal on border funding 'because he thought it would help him win the election. Which goes to show Donald Trump doesn't care about your security, he only cares about himself.'\n\nShe vowed to pass the legislation as president.\n\nThe border is one of the biggest vulnerabilities for the vice president. Her team has argued she was not in charge of border security but of handling the root causes of migration.\n\nVice President Kamala Harris repeatedly attacked Donald Trump at her rally\n\nHarris was in Georgia to try and bring the battleground state to her corner.\n\n'I am very clear. The path to the White House runs right through this state. We did it in 2020 and we're going to do it again in 2024,' she said.\n\nShe rattled off her resume as a prosecutor, district attorney and attorney general of California.\n\n'In those roles I took on perpetrators of all kinds, predators who abused women, fraudsters who ripped off consumers, cheaters who broke the rules for their own gain so hear me when I say, I know Donald Trump's type,' she said.\n\n'And I have been dealing with people like him my entire career,' she added.\n\n'Lock him up, lock him up,' the crowd demanded, their feet ponding on the bleachers.\n\nKamala Harris talks with reporters\n\nAnd when Harris noted Trump pulled out of their September debate, the crowd booed.\n\n'So he won't debate but he and his running mate have a lot to say about me,' she said. 'And, by the way, don't you find some of their stuff to be just plain weird.'\n\n'Well Donald I hope you'll reconsider to meet me on the debate stage because, as the saying goes, if you've got something to say' - the cheering of the crowd drowned her out.a\n\n'Lock him up,' the crowd yelled again.\n\nThere were 10,000 people cheering on the vice president in the Georgia State Convocation Center, according to the campaign.\n\nThe rally was Harris' largest campaign rally to date. It marks her first appearance in Georgia since she locked up the Democratic presidential nomination.\n\nTrump and Vance will hold a campaign rally in Atlanta together on Saturday August 3, the Trump campaign announced on Tuesday.\n\nIt will be held in the same location as Harris' rally.\n\nAhead of Harris' remarks, a bevy of top Democrats in the state fired up the crowd, repeatedly reminding the attendees about Trump's attempts to overturn the election results in Georgia in the 2020 election.\n\nMegan Thee Stallion fired up the crowd ahead of Harris' remarks.\n\n'We're about to make history with the first female president. The first black female president. Let's get this done honey,' she told the cheering crowd.\n\nShe sang 'Girls in the Hood,' 'Mamushi,' 'Body,' and 'Savage' (massive thanks to CNN's DJ Judd for helping your pooler with the song IDs).\n\nAs she sang her song 'Body' she told the crowd: 'Now I know my ladies in the crowd love their bodies - and if you want to keep loving your body, you know who to vote for.'\n\nStacey Abrams, who has been one of Harris' most ardent defenders, received a standing ovation and shouts of 'Stacey' when she came out. Abrams, in turn, had the crowd shout 'Kamala, Kamala.'\n\nShe described Harris as someone who 'break barriers' in the White House.\n\nShe noted that, in Georgia, 'we do the job of changing America and we're going to do it again.'\n\nRead More Trump plans to change Air Force One to new patriotic color despite dangerous side effect\n\nBut it was Georgia's two Democratic senators - who handed the party control of the Senate - that remided the crowd of Trump's actions in the last presidential race.\n\nSenator Jon Ossoff told the crowd: 'Apparently Donald Trump is too scared to debate Vice President Karris.'\n\nHe added that the candidate who is too scared is the 'candidate who is losing.'\n\n'Too scared,' the crowd yelled. 'Too scared.'\n\nOssoff also talked about Trump's attempts to overturn the election results in Georgia.\n\n'Lock him up, lock him up,' the crowd yelled.\n\nAnd Senator Raphael Warnock emphasized the state's importance in the race for the White House.\n\n'Everyone knows the road to the White House goes through Georgia,' he said.\n\nHe noted others know it. 'As a matter of fact I heard a phone call. A Florida man, called into Georgia and said I need 11,000 votes,' he said, referring to Trump's phone call to the state's secretary of state in 2020.\n\nThe crowd roared with laughter and applause.\n\n'Georgia - Donald Trump tried to steal your vote. Kamala Harris is trying to earn your vote,' Warnock said.\n\nFailed Governor candidate Stacey Abrams (left) and Senator Jon Ossoff (right) warmed up the crowd for Harris\n\nVice President Kamala Harris stops at Paschal's restaurant before her rally\n\nGeorgia played a crucial role in the last presidential election, and it is expected to be just as significant this November. According to several polls released last week, it's a virtual toss-up between Harris and Trump.\n\nPolls showed Joe Biden trailed Trump significantly in the state but Harris does much better against the former president.\n\nShe outperforms Biden among young people, Black voters, and Hispanic voters, key demographics that could decide swing states like Georgia and Arizona.\n\nBiden only won the state by some 12,000 votes in 2020, a win heavily contested by Trump, who is currently in the midst of an election interference case in the state\n\nGeorgia is a top focus with less than 100 days to go before the election.\n\nThe Harris campaign noted it has 24 offices open in the state nd 170 staffers on the ground there.\n\n'In Georgia, we're running the largest in state operation of any Democratic presidential campaign cycle ever,' campaign communications director Michael Tyler said.\n\nWhile in the state Harris plans to attack Trump for his ties to Project 2025 - an initiative from the Heritage Foundation that promotes conservative polices - and for his position on abortion rights.\n\nAnd while Harris focuses on Georgia, Trump will be focused on breaking the Democrats' blue wall.\n\nHe's holding a rally in Pennsylvania on Wednesday - his first visit back to the state since the assassination attempt on him in late June.\n\nHarris had surrogates in Pennsylvania on Monday to counter Trump - the state's Governor Josh Shapiro and Michigan Governor Gretchen Whitmore. Both Democrats have been names as possible Harris running mates.\n\nThe Harris campaign also has had surrogates Georgia, as she weighs who to pick as her number two.\n\nKentucky Gov. Andy Beshear, who is reported to be a potential running mate, was in in the state on Sunday.\n\nThe Harris campaign is vetting him along with several other candidates, including Sen. Mark Kelly of Arizona and Govs. Roy Cooper of North Carolina and Tim Walz of Minnesota.\n\nShe is expected to choose her vice presidential candidate by Aug. 7.\n\n'Not yet,' Harris told reporters on Tuesday when asked if she's picked her running mate.\n\nHarris' campaign noted it's held some 2,300 organizing events in battleground states this weekend as several high-profile Democrats on her potential VP list stumped for her.\n\nWith less than 100 days to go until Election Day, the Harris campaign is touting its fundraising and infrastructure, arguing it is well-positioned to beat Trump in November.\n\nThe campaign has taken in $200 million since Harris emerged as the likely Democratic presidential nominee last week.\n\nOver 170,000 volunteers have also signed up to help the Harris campaign with phone banking, canvassing and other get-out-the-vote efforts.", "source": {"uri": "dailymail.co.uk", "dataType": "news", "title": "Daily Mail Online"}, "authors": [], "concepts": {"uri": "8252116233", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "09:13:09", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T09:13:09Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T09:11:47Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6196078658103943, "url": "https://www.newsweek.com/kamala-harris-video-rally-leaving-1932421", "title": "Kamala Harris video appears to show people leaving rally mid-speech", "body": "A video from Vice President Kamala Harris' campaign rally in Atlanta on Tuesday appears to show attendees leaving mid-speech.\n\nOn X, formerly Twitter, Savanah Hernandez, a reporter for the conservative organization Turning Point USA, posted a video she said showed attendees leaving the rally while Harris was onstage. The reporter said Harris had been speaking for 15 minutes before people began to leave.\n\nIn the clip, some of the attendees can be seen holding \"Kamala\" signs, and it is unclear whether they were leaving the venue or had exited their seats for another reason, such as going to the restroom.\n\nRapper Megan Thee Stallion performed at the event before Harris spoke, and X users have theorized that rallygoers may have attended the event to see the performance.\n\nSince Biden ended his reelection bid on July 21 and endorsed Harris, the new presumptive Democratic presidential nominee has improved in polling among various demographics, including young people and Black voters, which could help her chances in some key swing states such as Georgia.\n\nNewsweek has contacted Harris' campaign for comment via email outside regular working hours.\n\nOn Truth Social, Donald Trump, the Republican presidential nominee, took a jab at Harris over the rally, writing: \"Crazy Kamala Harris, voted the WORST Vice President in American history, needed a concert to bring people into the Atlanta arena, and they started leaving 5 minutes into her speech. I don't need concerts or entertainers, I just have to MAKE AMERICA GREAT AGAIN!!!\"\n\nTrump has previously faced similar questions after scores of people were filmed appearing to leave his rallies early.\n\nThough some questioned whether rallygoers left early, others hailed the event as a triumph.\n\nOrganizers of the rally told The New York Times that about 10,000 people attended the event at the Georgia State University Convocation Center. The stadium's website says it has the capacity to accommodate up to 8,000.\n\nThe X account @harris_wins posted a video from the rally showing a boisterous crowd waving \"Kamala\" signs in the air.\n\n\"The media might not say it, but Democrats are by far more enthusiastic about electing Vice President Kamala Harris as President than Republicans are about electing Donald Trump,\" the pro-Harris account wrote.\n\nIn her speech, Harris made the case for her candidacy and challenged Trump to a debate.\n\n\"Donald, I do hope you'll reconsider to meet me on the debate stage because as the saying goes, if you got something to say, say it to my face,\" she said.\n\nIn 2020, Biden won Georgia by the narrowest margin of any state, less than 12,000 votes.\n\nPolls from recent months have generally shown Trump winning the state. rally", "body": "July 30 (UPI) -- Vice President Kamala Harris will travel to Atlanta on Tuesday to rally support for her presidential bid.\n\nGeorgia is a historically red state that voted Democrat in the 2020 presidential election, with President Joe Biden winning the state by 12,000 votes of former President Donald Trump and Democrats Jon Ossoff and Raphael Warnock elected to the Senate to help the party keep control of the chamber.\n\nHarris for President Communications Director Michael Taylor told a call with reporters Harris will \"continue to lay out her vision\" in Atlanta on Tuesday.\n\nOssoff, Warnock and Stacey Abrams, a former Georgia House member and gubernatorial candidate, will join Harris, who will be introduced by a graduate of historically Black Morehouse College.\n\nLocal Georgia reproductive rights advocates and rapper Megan Thee Stallion are expected to round out the speakers at Harris's rally, ABC News reported.\n\nSince Biden announced that he would leave the race, Harris' campaign has raised more than $200 million and signed up more than 170,000 volunteers.\n\n\"The vice president is energizing and mobilizing our base,\" Dan Kanninen, Harris's battleground state director said. \"Having a candidate who can mobilize our key Biden-Harris coalition, talking about the issues that resonate with Georgians ... make that state in play.\"\n\nKannienen said because of the closeness of the race in 2020, he expects Georgia to be even more competitive with the campaigning there more intense.\n\n\"I continue to be very clear with our partners and with our own staff,\" Kannienen said. \"This campaign will not get comfortable. We jumped in just 100 days ago against an opponent who has shown he's willing to do anything to win.\n\n\"This is going to be an incredibly close race just like it was in 2020. {"uri": "8251448570", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "22:57:45", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T22:57:45Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T22:56:11Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6196078658103943, "url": "https://www.thestar.com/news/world/united-states/thousands-in-atlanta-rally-for-harris-in-battleground-that-dems-feared-unwinnable-with-biden/article_f49bffca-f3fb-550d-b5d0-2892d5099ad0.html", "title": "Thousands in Atlanta rally for Harris in battleground that Dems feared unwinnable with Biden", "body": "ATLANTA (AP) -- Little more than a week ago, Georgia appeared to be slipping out of the Democrats' reach: President Joe Biden's campaign pledged to concentrate more on holding the Midwestern \"blue wall\" states and indicated they might be willing to forsake \"Sun Belt\" battlegrounds.\n\nBut now that Biden has bowed out of the race and Kamala Harris is the likely nominee, Democrats are expressing new hopes of an expanded electoral map and welcoming the vice president to the state that delivered Biden his narrowest victory margin in 2020 with a show of political force intended to signal a new landscape against Republican Donald Trump.\n\n\u00d7\n\nAlready a Subscriber? Sign in You are logged in Switch accounts\n\nThe roughly 8,000-capacity basketball arena at Georgia State University was filled to its rafters with thousands of voters waving signs, dancing to the Harris campaign soundtrack and celebrating an atmosphere that would not have been possible just 10 days ago, with the party reeling over whether the 81-year-old Biden would remain in the race after a dismal performance magnified concerns about his age and abilities.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\n\"This is like Barack Obama 2008 on steroids for me,\" said Mildred Hobson Doss, a 59-year-old who came downtown from suburban Lilburn. \"I would have voted for President Biden again. But we are ready.\"\n\nHarris is hoping a large rally, featuring a performance by hip-hop star Megan Thee Stallion, will help affirm her campaign's momentum. The campaign argues that Harris' appeal to young people, working-age women and non-white voters has scrambled the dynamics in Georgia and other states that are demographically similar, from North Carolina to Nevada and Arizona.\n\n\"The energy is infectious,\" said Georgia Democratic Chairwoman Nikema Williams, a congresswoman from Atlanta. \"My phone has been blowing up. People want to be part of this movement.\"\n\nIn a strategy memo released after the president left the race, Harris campaign chair Jen O'Malley Dillon, who held the same role for Biden, reaffirmed the importance of winning Michigan, Wisconsin and Pennsylvania, a trio of industrial states that have formed the traditional Democratic blue wall.\n\nBut she also argued that the vice president's place atop the ticket \"opens up additional persuadable voters\" and described them as \"disproportionately Black, Latino and under 30\" in places like Georgia.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW ARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\n\"This campaign is about freedom,\" said Georgia Sen. Raphael Warnock, who was there with his fellow Democratic Sen. Jon Ossoff. \"So the question is, do you want to be free? Or do you want to go back?\"\n\n\"When you show up, we win.\"\n\nRepublicans, who still control Georgia's state government, counter that Biden's lagging popularity and concern over higher consumer prices and immigration will transfer to Harris in the historically conservative state.\n\nBut they concede that the landscape suddenly looks much closer to 2020 - when Biden won by about 0.25 percentage points -- than when Trump was riding high after the Republican National Convention and surviving an assassination attempt.\n\n\"Trump was going to win Georgia. It was over,\" said Republican consultant Brian Robinson. \"The Democrats have a chance here for a reset.\"\n\nAnd Trump is not taking chances. Earlier Tuesday, the former president announced that he would come to Atlanta on Saturday for a rally in the same Georgia State arena.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW ARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nRobinson said Harris still has plenty of liabilities, including the progressive positions she took in her failed 2020 primary campaign and her various rhetorical stumbles. But he said Harris so far in this campaign has been \"in command,\" and if that continues, \"we have a new ballgame and she will be competitive in Georgia.\"\n\nTrump campaign spokesperson Karoline Leavitt dismissed Harris as \"just as weak, failed and incompetent as Joe Biden\" and said the vice president would have to explain her support of Biden administration policies that \"hurt working families in Georgia over the past four years.\"\n\nThe Harris campaign and Georgia Democratic officials have 24 offices across the state, including two added last weekend in metro Atlanta. Trump and the Republican National Committee opened their first Georgia offices only recently.\n\nDemocrats are betting that a combination of high turnout among traditional, core Democratic constituencies, as well as a strong showing in the suburbs and small pickups elsewhere, can be enough for Harris to carry Georgia.\n\nGeorgia Gov. Brian Kemp, a Republican, said in a recent interview that the best GOP campaigns can win comfortably in Georgia but bad efforts -- combined with strong Democratic campaigns -- lose. Kemp, for example, won reelection by 7.5 percentage points in 2022 over national Democratic star Stacey Abrams. Yet in the same election cycle, Georgians reelected Democratic Sen. Raphael Warnock over his Republican challenger Herschel Walker, who was endorsed by Trump.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW ARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nIn recent elections, Democrats have held wide advantages in the core of metro Atlanta, where Jayapal spoke. The party also performed well in Columbus and Savannah, as well as some rural, majority-Black counties. But Republicans dominated in other rural areas and small towns and cities -- where Trump has held multiple rallies in recent years.\n\nThe fast-growing, diversifying Atlanta suburbs and exurbs offer the most opportunity for swings, especially from GOP-leaning moderates disenchanted with Trump.\n\nFor Harris, that means depending on voters as varied as Michael Sleister, a white suburbanite, and Allen Smith, a Black man who lives not far from downtown Atlanta.\n\nSleister, who considers himself an independent, has lived in Forsyth County for 35 years. \"I've voted Republican many times in my life,\" he said, but not since the GOP took a rightward turn during President Barack Obama's administration.\n\n\"Now I see the Republican Party as representing a direct threat to my grandchildren,\" he said, adding that he sees Trump \"as just a horrible person.\"\n\nSmith is a 41-year-old Atlanta native who has become a first-time campaign volunteer since Harris became the likely nominee.\n\n\"I was driving when I heard the news about President Biden endorsing her, and I started pounding my fist -- I decided right then I would do whatever I could to help her get elected,\" Smith said.\n\n___\n\nFollow the AP's coverage of the 2024 election at https://apnews.com/hub/election-2024.\n\nRead more on the U.S. Election at thestar.com", "source": {"uri": "thestar.com", "dataType": The momentum in this race is shifting, and \"Donald Trump is feeling it,\" she said.\n\nWith less than 100 days left in one of the least predictable campaign seasons in recent history, Democrats are redrawing their map to victory, hoping the prospect of the first Black and Asian woman president can motivate Democrats to the polls.\n\n\"We are not going back,\" Ms Harris said to cheers and chants of about 10,000 attendees.\n\nMegan Thee Stallion, whose album \"Megan\" recently launched at No. 1 on Billboard's Top R&B/Hip-Hop albums chart, performed in a blue pantsuit and tie, the colour associated with Ms Harris' Democratic Party.\n\nShe joins a host of musicians who have recently come out in support of Ms Harris' bid to become the Democratic presidential nominee in the Nov 5 election.\n\nGeorgia Senator Jon Ossoff, a Democrat, said on MSNBC over the weekend that Ms Harris' entry into the race \"has put Georgia in play\" for Democrats and predicted she will win.\n\nSwing states like Georgia, which Democrats barely won in a hard-fought battle in 2020, are fiercely contested because they can lean either to Republicans or Democrats and play a decisive role in presidential elections.\n\nFiveThirtyEight, the poll aggregation site, shows Republican Donald Trump leading Ms Harris by between one and five percentage points in surveys taken after Ms Harris became the likely Democratic candidate.\n\nPresident Joe Biden ended his reelection bid on July 22 and endorsed Ms Harris for the Nov 5 vote against Trump. Since then, Ms Harris' election campaign has raised US$200 million (S$270 million), signed up 170,000 new volunteers and she has significantly outperformed Mr Biden in recent polling among young people, Black voters and Hispanic voters.\n\nA New York Times/Siena College national poll published on July 25 found Ms Harris has narrowed a sizeable Trump lead, while Trump had a two percentage point lead in a Wall Street Journal poll published on July 26. A Reuters/Ipsos poll published July 23 showed a two point lead for Ms Harris.\n\nMr Biden's campaign saw a narrowing path to victory with the \"Sun Belt states,\" including Georgia, Arizona and Nevada, as unlikely wins. Georgia backed Mr Biden by 0.2 percentage points, just under 12,000 votes in 2020, and Trump by around 5 percentage points in 2016.\n\nMr Andy Beshear, the twice-elected Democratic governor of deep-red Kentucky, visited Georgia over the weekend to campaign for Ms Harris in the Republican stronghold of Forsyth County.\n\nThe Harris campaign is vetting him along with Senator Mark Kelly of Arizona, Governor Josh Shapiro of Pennsylvania and Governor Tim Walz of Minnesota as possible vice presidential candidates. {"uri": "8251539632", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "00:54:56", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T00:54:56Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T00:51:09Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.615686297416687, "url": "https://www.thestar.com/news/world/united-states/at-boisterous-georgia-rally-harris-dares-trump-to-say-it-to-my-face-and-debate/article_f49bffca-f3fb-550d-b5d0-2892d5099ad0.html", "title": "At boisterous Georgia rally, Harris dares Trump to 'say it to my face' and debate her", "body": "ATLANTA (AP) -- Vice President Kamala Harris told a cheering, boisterous, packed Atlanta arena on Tuesday that the next 98 days would be a fight, but they'd win come November, as she taunted Donald Trump for wavering on whether he'd show up for their upcoming debate.\n\n\"The momentum in this race is shifting,\" the likely nominee said. \"And there are signs Donald Trump is feeling it.\"\n\n\u00d7\n\nAlready a Subscriber? Sign in You are logged in Switch accounts\n\nLittle more than a week ago, Georgia appeared to be slipping out of the Democrats' reach: President Joe Biden's campaign pledged to concentrate more on holding the Midwestern \"blue wall\" states and indicated they might be willing to forsake \"Sun Belt\" battlegrounds. But now that Biden has bowed out of the race and Harris is the likely nominee, Democrats are expressing new hopes of an expanded electoral map.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nIn the state that delivered Biden his narrowest victory margin in 2020, Harris pulled off what has been a signature Trump event: A big, loud rally full of supporters cheering her name, as she mocked her rival and his running mate JD Vance as \"just plain weird,\" and derided their policies as backward, outdated and dangerous.\n\nHarris mentioned Trump's efforts to stop the passage of an immigration bill that had bipartisan support and would have been among the strongest border security in decades. She said she'd work to push the bill across the finish line. \"I will bring back the border security bill that Donald Trump killed and I will sign it and show Donald Trump what real leadership looks like.\"\n\nTrump earlier said he'd debate Harris, but is now questioning the value of a meetup and saying he \"probably\" will debate her, but he \"can also make a case for not doing it.\"\n\nHarris seized on it. \"So he won't debate me, but he and his running mate have a lot to say about me,\" she said. \"And by the way, don't you find some of their stuff to just be plain weird.\"\n\n\"Well Donald,\" she said, addressing him head-on. \"I do hope you'll reconsider. Meet me on the debate stage ... because as the saying goes, if you've got something to say, say it to my face.\" Trump has suggested the Sept. 10 debate on ABC News should be moved to a different network, calling ABC \"fake news.\"\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW ARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nThe roughly 8,000-capacity basketball arena at Georgia State University was filled to its rafters with voters waving signs, dancing to the Harris campaign soundtrack and a performance by Megan Thee Stallion. Such an atmosphere would not have been possible just 10 days ago, with the party reeling over whether the 81-year-old Biden would remain in the race after a dismal performance magnified concerns about his age and abilities and ultimately ended his campaign.\n\n\"This is like Barack Obama 2008 on steroids for me,\" said Mildred Hobson Doss, a 59-year-old who came downtown from suburban Lilburn. \"I would have voted for President Biden again. But we are ready.\"\n\nHarris' campaign argues her appeal to young people, working-age women and non-white voters has scrambled the dynamics in Georgia and other states that are demographically similar, from North Carolina to Nevada and Arizona.\n\nIn a strategy memo released after the president left the race, Harris campaign chair Jen O'Malley Dillon, who held the same role for Biden, reaffirmed the importance of winning Michigan, Wisconsin and Pennsylvania, a trio of industrial states that have formed the traditional Democratic blue wall.\n\nBut she also argued that the vice president's place atop the ticket \"opens up additional persuadable voters\" and described them as \"disproportionately Black, Latino and under 30\" in places like Georgia.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW ARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\n\"The energy is infectious,\" said Georgia Democratic Chairwoman Nikema Williams, a congresswoman from Atlanta. \"My phone has been blowing up. People want to be part of this movement.\"\n\nHarris began Tuesday with her days as a prosecutor -- setting up the contrast between the law and Trump's many legal problems and misdeeds. But she also aggressively defended the Biden administration's record and she'd work to pass voting rights legislation and work to restore reproductive rights stripped by the fall of Roe v. Wade.\n\n\"America has tried these failed policies before. And we are not going back. We're not going back,\" she said, shaking her head no as the crowd cheered \"we're not going back.\"\n\nRepublicans, who still control Georgia's state government, counter that Biden's lagging popularity and concern over higher consumer prices and immigration will transfer to Harris in the historically conservative state.\n\nBut they concede that the landscape suddenly looks much closer to 2020 - when Biden won by about 0.25 percentage points -- than when Trump was riding high after the Republican National Convention and surviving an assassination attempt.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW ARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\n\"Trump was going to win Georgia. It was over,\" said Republican consultant Brian Robinson. \"The Democrats have a chance here for a reset.\"\n\nAnd Trump is not taking chances. Earlier Tuesday, the former president announced that he would come to Atlanta on Saturday for a rally in the same Georgia State arena.\n\nRobinson said Harris still has plenty of liabilities, including the progressive positions she took in her failed 2020 primary campaign and her various rhetorical stumbles. But he said Harris so far in this campaign has been \"in command,\" and if that continues, \"we have a new ballgame and she will be competitive in Georgia.\"\n\nTrump campaign spokesperson Karoline Leavitt dismissed Harris as \"just as weak, failed and incompetent as Joe Biden\" and said the vice president would have to explain her support of Biden administration policies that \"hurt working families in Georgia over the past four years.\"\n\nThe campaign and Georgia Democratic officials have 24 offices across the state, including two added last weekend in metro Atlanta. Trump and the Republican National Committee opened their first Georgia offices only recently.\n\nIn a call with supporters after her speech, Harris thanked them for their work and noted early voting starts in some states in just 38 days. She hasn't yet formally seized the nomination, nor picked a running mate; both are expected soon.\n\n\"This is a sprint,\" she said. \"And we know what we need to do to cross the finish line.\"\n\nThe fast-growing, diversifying Atlanta suburbs and exurbs offer the most opportunity for swings, especially from GOP-leaning moderates disenchanted with Trump.\n\nFor Harris, that means depending on voters as varied as Michael Sleister, a white suburbanite, and Allen Smith, a Black man who lives not far from downtown Atlanta.\n\nSleister, who considers himself an independent, has lived in Forsyth County for 35 years. \"I've voted Republican many times in my life,\" he said, but not since the GOP took a rightward turn during President Barack Obama's administration.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW ARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\n\"Now I see the Republican Party as representing a direct threat to my grandchildren,\" he said, adding that he sees Trump \"as just a horrible person.\"\n\nSmith is a 41-year-old Atlanta native who has become a first-time campaign volunteer since Harris became the likely nominee.\n\n\"I was driving when I heard the news about President Biden endorsing her, and I started pounding my fist -- I decided right then I would do whatever I could to help her get elected,\" Smith said.\n\n___\n\nLong reported from Washington. Follow the AP's coverage of the 2024 election at https://apnews.com/hub/election-2024.\n\nRead more on the U.S. Election at thestar.com", "source": {"uri": "thestar.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "title": "Crowd erupts as Kamala Harris issues challenge to Trump at rally", "body": "US Vice President Kamala Harris has challenged Donald Trump to a presidential debate before Americans head to polls to decide the next leader of the free world.\n\nThe Republican nominee this week appeared to backtrack from an earlier commitment to debate his rival, saying he \"probably\" will but \"can also make a case for not doing it\".\n\nThe 78-year-old was pressed multiple times in an interview with Fox News and insisted he wanted to debate Ms Harris but added: \"Everybody knows who I am.\"\n\n\"The answer is yes, I'll probably end up debating,\" Mr Trump said.\n\nMs Harris on Tuesday night (local time) continued her presidential campaign across the United States as she stopped in Atlanta, Georgia, for a raucous rally.\n\nSome 10,000 supporters gathered at the Georgia State University Convocation Centre to watch the VP's event attended by Democrats and celebrities.\n\nIn her 21-minute speech, she pointed to the differences in her policies compared to Republicans, such as on border security and propping up middle Americans.\n\nBut towards the end of her address, Ms Harris challenged Trump to the debate he had previously agreed to when US President Joe Biden was the favoured nominee.\n\n\"Well Donald,\" she said with a dramatic pause as the crowd's cheers grew louder, \"I do hope you'll reconsider to meet me on the debate stage.\"\n\n\"Because as the saying goes, 'If you've got something to say, say it to my face'.\"\n\nMs Harris also suggested, \"The momentum in this race is shifting and there are signs that Donald Trump is feeling it (the competition).\"\n\nGeorgia is one of the key battleground states in the election.\n\nIt has largely been won by Republicans, but that shifted in 2020 when Mr Biden narrowly edged out Mr Trump by 0.02 per cent of the vote.\n\nIt was also the same state where President Joe Biden had his first debate with Mr Trump, which was later labelled as \"disastrous\" due to his ability to answer questions.\n\nMs Harris insisted Georgia is a must-win state for her path to the White House.\n\n\"You all helped us win in 2020 and we are going to do it again in 2024,\" she told the rally.\n\nThe campaign was also attended by Grammy-winning American rapper Megan Thee Stallion who performed her hit song Savage and new track Mamushi.\n\nMs Harris last week secured enough support from delegates to become the Democratic presidential nominee ahead of the party's national convention on August 19-22.\n\nHowever, she has yet to pick a running mate and prior to Tuesday's rally, she said she had \"not yet\" made a decision.\n\nThere have been suggestions she will name her vice presidential candidate early next week, before going on the campaign trail.\n\nMeanwhile, Mr Trump and his running mate JD Vance will hold their first joint rally in Atlanta at the same venue as Ms Harris' campaign on Tuesday.", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "8251395888", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "21:58:15", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T21:58:15Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T21:55:58Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6117647290229797, "url": "https://www.thestar.com/news/world/united-states/large-rally-in-atlanta-set-to-welcome-harris-in-battleground-that-dems-feared-unwinnable-with/article_f49bffca-f3fb-550d-b5d0-2892d5099ad0.html", "title": "Large rally in Atlanta set to welcome Harris in battleground that Dems feared unwinnable with Biden", "body": "ATLANTA (AP) -- Little more than a week ago, Georgia appeared to be slipping out of the Democrats' reach: President Joe Biden's campaign pledged to concentrate more on holding the Midwestern \"blue wall\" states and indicated they might be willing to forsake \"Sun Belt\" battlegrounds.\n\nBut now that Biden has bowed out of the race and Kamala Harris is the likely nominee, Democrats are expressing new hopes of an expanded electoral map and welcoming the vice president to the state that delivered Biden his narrowest victory margin in 2020 with a show of political force intended to signal a new landscape against Republican Donald Trump.\n\n\u00d7\n\nAlready a Subscriber? Sign in You are logged in Switch accounts\n\nTwo hours before Harris was expected to take the stage, the basketball arena at Georgia State University was filled to its rafters with thousands of voters waving signs, dancing to the Harris campaign soundtrack and celebrating an atmosphere that would not have been possible just 10 days ago, with the party reeling over whether the 81-year-old Biden would remain in the race after a dismal performance magnified concerns about his age and abilities.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\n\"This is like Barack Obama 2008 on steroids for me,\" said Mildred Hobson Doss, a 59-year-old who came downtown from suburban Lilburn. \"I would have voted for President Biden again. But we are ready.\"\n\nHarris is hoping a large rally, featuring a performance by hip-hop star Megan Thee Stallion, will help affirm her campaign's momentum. The campaign argues that Harris' appeal to young people, working-age women and non-white voters has scrambled the dynamics in Georgia and other states that are demographically similar, from North Carolina to Nevada and Arizona.\n\n\"The energy is infectious,\" said Georgia Democratic Chairwoman Nikema Williams, a congresswoman from Atlanta. \"My phone has been blowing up. People want to be part of this movement.\"\n\nIn a strategy memo released after the president left the race, Harris campaign chair Jen O'Malley Dillon, who held the same role for Biden, reaffirmed the importance of winning Michigan, Wisconsin and Pennsylvania, a trio of industrial states that have formed the traditional Democratic blue wall.\n\nBut she also argued that the vice president's place atop the ticket \"opens up additional persuadable voters\" and described them as \"disproportionately Black, Latino and under 30\" in places like Georgia.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW ARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nRepublicans, who still control Georgia's state government, counter that Biden's lagging popularity and concern over higher consumer prices and immigration will transfer to Harris in the historically conservative state.\n\nBut they concede that the landscape suddenly looks much closer to 2020 - when Biden won by about 0.25 percentage points -- than when Trump was riding high after the Republican National Convention and surviving an assassination attempt.\n\n\"Trump was going to win Georgia. It was over,\" said Republican consultant Brian Robinson. \"The Democrats have a chance here for a reset.\"\n\nAnd Trump is not taking chances. Earlier Tuesday, the former president announced that he would come to Atlanta on Saturday for a rally in the same Georgia State arena.\n\nRobinson said Harris still has plenty of liabilities, including the progressive positions she took in her failed 2020 primary campaign and her various rhetorical stumbles. But he said Harris so far in this campaign has been \"in command,\" and if that continues \"we have a new ballgame and she will be competitive in Georgia.\"\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW ARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nTrump campaign spokesperson Karoline Leavitt dismissed Harris as \"just as weak, failed and incompetent as Joe Biden\" and said the vice president would have to explain her support of Biden administration policies that \"hurt working families in Georgia over the past four years.\"\n\nThe Harris campaign and Georgia Democratic officials have 24 offices across the state, including two added last weekend in metro Atlanta. Trump and the Republican National Committee opened their first Georgia offices only recently.\n\nDemocrats are betting that a combination of high turnout among traditional, core Democratic constituencies, as well as a strong showing in the suburbs and small pickups elsewhere, can be enough for Harris to carry Georgia. That approach was on display at the weekend office openings.\n\nOn Saturday, the venue was East Point, a majority Black municipality and Democratic stronghold south of Atlanta. Congressional Progressive Caucus Chair Pramila Jayapal, D-Wash., was the featured guest, telling a crowd of mostly Black women that they were the key to victory -- \"the people who are really going to save the country.\"\n\nA day later, it was Kentucky Gov. Andy Beshear, among several contenders Harris is considering for her running mate, campaigning in Forsyth County. The area is historically very conservative, though Democrats have narrowed the GOP margins in recent cycles.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW ARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\n\"Every county matters,\" Beshear said, holding out his ability to win two governor's races in Kentucky despite Trump's domination of the state in presidential elections.\n\nGeorgia Gov. Brian Kemp, a Republican, said in a recent interview that the best GOP campaigns can win comfortably in Georgia but bad efforts -- combined with strong Democratic campaigns -- lose. Kemp, for example, won reelection by 7.5 percentage points in 2022 over national Democratic star Stacey Abrams. Yet in the same election cycle, Georgians reelected Democratic Sen. Raphael Warnock over his Republican challenger Herschel Walker, who was endorsed by Trump.\n\nIn recent elections, Democrats have held wide advantages in the core of metro Atlanta, where Jayapal spoke. The party also performed well in Columbus and Savannah, as well as some rural, majority-Black counties. But Republicans dominated in other rural areas and small towns and cities -- where Trump has held multiple rallies in recent years.\n\nThe fast-growing, diversifying Atlanta suburbs and exurbs, like those where Beshear campaigned on Sunday, offer the most opportunity for swings, especially from GOP-leaning moderates disenchanted with Trump.\n\nFor Harris, that means depending on voters as varied as Michael Sleister, a white suburbanite, and Allen Smith, a Black man who lives not far from downtown Atlanta.\n\nSleister, who considers himself an independent, has lived in Forsyth County for 35 years. \"I've voted Republican many times in my life,\" he said, but not since the GOP took a rightward turn during President Barack Obama's administration.\n\n\"Now I see the Republican Party as representing a direct threat to my grandchildren,\" he said, adding that he sees Trump \"as just a horrible person.\"\n\nSmith is a 41-year-old Atlanta native who has become a first-time campaign volunteer since Harris became the likely nominee.\n\n\"I was driving when I heard the news about President Biden endorsing her, and I started pounding my fist -- I decided right then I would do whatever I could to help her get elected,\" Smith said.\n\n___\n\nFollow the AP's coverage of the 2024 election at https://apnews.com/hub/election-2024.\n\nRead more on the U.S. Election at J.D. {"uri": "8252115546", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "09:12:01", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T09:12:01Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T09:11:21Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6117647290229797, "url": "https://www.npr.org/2024/07/31/nx-s1-5056189/kamala-harris-donald-trump-battleground-georgia-rally", "title": "Here comes the Sun (Belt): With Harris running, the presidential map has shifted back", "body": "ATLANTA -- President Biden's decision to drop out of the presidential race may have reset the states considered up for grabs in November, as both major-party campaigns shift their attention to the Sun Belt once again.\n\nThe seven states decided by narrow margins in 2020 -- Arizona, Georgia, Michigan, Nevada, North Carolina, Pennsylvania and Wisconsin -- are the primary focus of Vice President Harris and former President Donald Trump with fewer than 100 days until Election Day -- and with early voting set to begin in many places weeks before that.\n\nFour years ago, Biden narrowly won all of those states except North Carolina by stitching together a diverse coalition of voters that also gave the campaign multiple pathways to win.\n\nBut following his disastrous debate performance a month ago, polling averages showed him losing to Trump nationwide, and trailing outside the margin of error in every battleground state except the so-called \"Blue Wall\" states of Michigan, Pennsylvania and Wisconsin.\n\nNow, with Harris replacing Biden as the likely Democratic nominee, early surveys of the new presidential race show a changing contest that is close, driven by a surge in Democratic enthusiasm and Harris winning back younger, nonwhite voters that had soured on Biden.\n\nThose shifting coalitions point to improved chances for Democrats in the more diverse Sun Belt swing states of Arizona, Georgia, North Carolina and Nevada -- and put the original battleground map back into place.\n\nThe latest NPR/PBS News/Marist national poll shows a statistical tie between Harris and Trump, both head to head and in a larger contest that includes minor party and independent candidates. Several state-level polls in swing states since Harris announced her candidacy show a tighter race as well.\n\nThe candidates themselves have both implicitly and explicitly acknowledged the altered political map. On the airwaves, both campaigns are launching multimillion-dollar ad buys in the key battleground states. Harris' campaign is running a spot that highlights her background as a prosecutor and Trump's video attacks Harris as weak on immigration issues.\n\nHarris held a rally in Atlanta Tuesday night, the largest of the campaign so far, in front of thousands of supporters at Georgia State University's Convocation Center.\n\n\"Georgia, it is so good to be back, and I am very clear: The path to the White House runs right through this state,\" Harris said to a filled 10,000-person arena. \"And you all helped us win in 2020 -- and we're gonna do it again in 2024!\"\n\nTrump and his vice presidential nominee, Ohio U.S. Sen. JD Vance, will hold a rally at the same location on Saturday.\n\nGeorgia in particular is seen as an opportunity for the Harris campaign to improve before Election Day.\n\nNearly a third of the electorate is Black, Atlanta's suburbs are home to a sizable share of moderate voters who have voted for Republicans and Democrats in past elections, and the Harris campaign says it is making record staffing investments.\n\n\"In Georgia, we're running the largest in-state operation of any Democratic presidential campaign cycle ever,\" Harris campaign communications director Michael Tyler said to reporters. \"Since the vice president began her candidacy, we've seen tremendous energy on the ground.\"\n\nThe Trump campaign is not ceding focus on the Sun Belt, though.\n\nVance is campaigning in Nevada and Arizona this week, with a planned appearance at the U.S. southern border on Thursday.\n\nArizona and Georgia are also two primary states where Republicans' \"Trump Force 47\" campaign strategy to use volunteers to lead targeted get-out-the-vote efforts is in full swing.\n\nAs both Trump and Harris continue to make their case to voters in these swing states over the next three months, there are still several key events that could continue to shape the contour of the race, like Harris naming her vice presidential pick, the Democratic National Convention next month in Chicago and any potential debates between Trump and Harris before voting begins.\n\nHarris is set to announce her running mate within days, and the campaign says they will do a series of rallies, a tour that will begin on Tuesday and take them to Philadelphia, western Wisconsin, Detroit, Raleigh, N.C., Savannah, Ga., Phoenix and Las Vegas.", "source": {"uri": "npr.org", "dataType": "news", "title": And we are the underdogs in this race.\"\n\nHarris's nascent presidential bid took off following Biden's July 21 exit from the race, with much of the party coalescing behind her and her campaign raising a staggering $200 million.\n\n\"The momentum in this race is shifting, and there are signs that Donald Trump is feeling it,\" she said.\n\nThe Republican nominee recently said he would forego political tradition and not debate Harris and also unleashed a barrage of insults against his rival, calling her \"crazy\" and a \"bum.\"\n\n\"Well Donald, I do hope you'll reconsider to meet me on the debate stage, because as the saying goes, if you've got something to say, say it to my face,\" Harris said, to roars of approval.\n\nHarris also repeated her popular line about how, as a former prosecutor and California attorney general going up against predators and fraudsters, she knows \"Donald Trump's type.\"\n\n\"In this campaign, I will proudly put my record against his any day of the week,\" she said.\n\n'Extreme abortion bans'\n\nWith just 98 days before the election, Harris is under pressure to announce her vice presidential pick. Asked Tuesday whether she had chosen one, Harris told reporters: \"Not yet.\"\n\nThe search must be nearing a conclusion, however, as her team announced Tuesday that Harris and her new running mate would campaign next week in battlegrounds Pennsylvania, Wisconsin, Michigan, North Carolina, Georgia, Arizona and Nevada.\n\nWith the White House race turned on its head, 59-year-old Harris on Tuesday unveiled her first television ad since replacing Biden, while the Trump camp released a dueling spot attacking her on the crucial election issue of immigration.\n\nHarris swatted away the attack, saying in her speech that while the Biden administration worked with conservatives to craft critical border legislation, Trump \"tanked\" it for political gain.\n\n\"Donald Trump does not care about border security,\" she said. \"He only cares about himself.\"\n\nHarris said if elected she would focus on key economic goals such as expanding affordable health care and tackling rising consumer costs.\n\nShe also attacked Trump, 78, over his \"extreme abortion bans,\" referring to restrictive new laws enacted in several states in the two years since the US Supreme Court -- featuring three justices nominated by Trump -- stripped constitutional protections for abortion.\n\nGeorgia in play\n\nAs for Georgia's potential competitiveness, Harris insisted \"the path to the White House runs right through this state.\"\n\nIn a sign the southern state will be bitterly contested, Trump and his running mate J.D. Vance announced they would hold their own rally Saturday in Atlanta.\n\n\"Kamala Harris and her complicit cronies have made the great people of Georgia pay a hefty price for their woke policies,\" the Trump campaign said Tuesday.\n\nHarris took over a bleak electoral map from the faltering Biden, with Democrats' hopes entirely based on the three Rust Belt post-industrial states of Michigan, Wisconsin and Pennsylvania.\n\nBut they are now looking again at other \"sunbelt\" states such as Georgia, Arizona and Nevada, all of which Democrats narrowly won in 2020.\n\nVance addressed a rally Tuesday in Henderson, Nevada, where he attacked Harris as \"dangerously liberal,\" while Trump campaigns in Pennsylvania on Wednesday.\n\nPromotedListen to the latest songs, only on Raphael Warnock and Jon Ossoff.\n\nSongs spanning musical genres - from Whitney Houston to Migos - blasted through the speakers. I was a courtroom prosecutor,\" Harris said. \"So in those roles, I took on perpetrators of all kinds; predators who broke the rules for their own game.\"\n\nShe went on to discuss her time as attorney general for California.\n\n\"As attorney general, I held the big Wall Street banks accountable for fraud,\" Harris said. \"Donald Trump was just found guilty of fraud. In her first big rally as the nominee, the vice president called out the three-time Republican presidential candidate to keep his word about the ABC News-hosted debate set for September 10 that he had previously agreed to do against Biden.\n\n\"So the momentum in this race is shifting, and there are signs that Donald Trump is feeling it,\" the veep and presumptive Democratic nominee told an enthusiastic crowd of more than 10,000 just now in Atlanta as polls have Harris tied and even ahead of Trump a week into her White House bid. And we are the underdogs in this race.\"\n\nHarris's nascent presidential bid took off following Biden's July 21 exit from the race, with much of the party coalescing behind her and her campaign raising a staggering $200 million.\n\n\"The momentum in this race is shifting, and there are signs that Donald Trump is feeling it,\" she said.\n\nThe Republican nominee recently said he would forego political tradition and not debate Harris, and also unleashed a barrage of insults against his rival, calling her \"crazy\" and a \"bum.\"\n\n\"Well Donald, I do hope you'll reconsider to meet me on the debate stage, because as the saying goes, if you've got something to say, say it to my face,\" Harris said, to roars of approval.\n\nHarris also repeated her popular line about how, as a former prosecutor and California attorney general going up against predators and fraudsters, she knows \"Donald Trump's type.\"\n\n\"In this campaign, I will proudly put my record against his any day of the week,\" she said.\n\nWith just 98 days before the election, Harris is under pressure to announce her vice presidential pick. Asked Tuesday whether she had chosen one, Harris told reporters: \"Not yet.\"\n\nThe search must be nearing a conclusion, however, as her team announced Tuesday that Harris and her new running mate would campaign next week in battlegrounds Pennsylvania, Wisconsin, Michigan, North Carolina, Georgia, Arizona and Nevada.\n\nWith the White House race turned on its head, 59-year-old Harris on Tuesday unveiled her first television ad since replacing Biden, while the Trump camp released a dueling spot attacking her on the crucial election issue of immigration.\n\nHarris swatted away the attack, Since then, Harris' election campaign has raised $200 million, signed up 170,000 new volunteers and she has significantly outperformed Biden in recent polling among young people, Black voters and Hispanic voters.\n\nA New York Times/Siena College national poll published Thursday found Harris has narrowed a sizable Trump lead, while Trump had a two percentage point lead in a Wall Street Journal poll published on Friday. A Reuters/Ipsos poll published July 23 showed a two point lead for Harris.\n\nBiden's campaign saw a narrowing path to victory with the \"Sun Belt states,\" including Georgia, Arizona and Nevada, as unlikely wins. Georgia backed Biden by 0.2 percentage points, just under 12,000 votes in 2020, and Trump by around 5 percentage points in 2016.\n\nAndy Beshear, the twice-elected Democratic governor of deep-red Kentucky, visited Georgia over the weekend to campaign for Harris in the Republican stronghold of Forsyth County.\n\nThe Harris campaign is vetting him along with Senator Mark Kelly of Arizona, Governor Josh Shapiro of Pennsylvania and Governor Tim Walz of Minnesota as possible vice presidential candidates. A decision is expected by Aug. 7.\n\nHarris is leaning into her resume as a former district attorney and California attorney general, seeking to draw a contrast with Trump who is the first former president to be convicted of felony crimes.\n\nTrump and 14 co-defendants are accused of racketeering and other charges for their role in attempting to overturn Biden's narrow win in Georgia.\n\n(Reporting by Nandita Bose in Washington; Additional reporting by Trevor Hunnicutt; Editing by Heather Timmons, Stephen Coates, Deepa Babington and Chris Reese)", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "8252304459", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "11:02:48", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T11:02:48Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T11:02:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5843137502670288, "url": "https://www.rollingstone.com/politics/politics-features/kamala-harris-atlanta-rally-megan-thee-stallion-quavo-1235071150/", "title": "Kamala Harris Hard Launches Her 2024 Campaign in Atlanta", "body": "ATLANTA -- Two weeks ago, staffers working for the major Democratic campaigns and party committees were demoralized and depressed, their dream jobs transformed into a joyless death march. Donations were drying up, while candidates and elected officials were speaking openly and with a grave certainty that the party was destined for an extinction-level electoral wipeout in November.\n\nIn the world of two weeks ago, the graphic Democratic euphoria on display in Atlanta Tuesday would have been almost inconceivable: a Division I basketball arena packed so full of ecstatic supporters that the fire marshal was refusing to let anyone else in. There was simply no space left. Ticket holders, credentialed press, elected officials who failed to make it inside the Georgia Convocation Center lined the barricades along Capitol Avenue, in the 91-degree heat, to watch a succession of celebrities on the Jumbotron.\n\nIt's been just ten days since Joe Biden withdrew from the 2024 presidential campaign, and the vibe shift was spectacular. Vice President Kamala Harris' Atlanta rally -- the first bonafide campaign event since she took control of the Democratic ticket -- had the energy of a homecoming rally. Stacey Abrams, Sen. Jon Ossoff, and Sen. Raphael Warnock spoke. Megan Thee Stallion stunted on stage, a \"Hotties for Harris\" banner billowing in the stands behind her. \"I know my ladies in the crowd love their bodies,\" she said. \"And if you want to keep loving your body, you know who to vote for.\" Quavo of Migos introduced the guy who introduced the vice president.\n\nPeggy Golden traveled from her home in Savannah to be here: \"This is history,\" she says. Golden is going to be 79 in December; she was born before the Civil Rights movement began. \"I was brought up on a plantation,\" she says. Her parents were a cook and caretaker. \"I didn't expect it to happen in my lifetime -- and, hey, here it is,\" she says of seeing a woman -- a black woman -- become president. \"I feel it in my bones that it's going to happen.\"\n\nBut for all the excitement -- and there seemed to be an endless supply of it in Atlanta -- some attendees were still reeling from the political whiplash of the last few weeks. \"I loved Biden and I was heartbroken when he dropped out of the race,\" Lynda Cosby-Pinnock says. And she cautions Harris still has work to do to convince members of her own community she deserves their support, \"Some people say they don't know who she is, they're not sure what she stands for,\" she says.\n\nSydney Rhodes, a 28-year-old influencer, says she was always going to vote for the Democratic candidate: \"I would vote for anybody besides Donald Trump and Project 2025.\" But, she adds, \"I think a lot of people are unsure because of the quick switch, and I hear a lot of people talk about her past as a prosecutor.\"\n\nHarris, for her part, is not shying away from her history as a prosecutor, district attorney, or attorney general. On stage in Atlanta, she lead with what has become her signature line: \"In those roles, I took on perpetrators of all kinds: predators who abused women, fraudsters who ripped off consumers, cheaters who broke the rules for their own gain -- so hear me when I say I know Donald Trump's type.\"\n\nAnd in Atlanta, Harris showed a new willingness to place, at the center of the campaign, an issue Republicans are convinced is her biggest weakness: immigration.\n\n\"I was the attorney general of a border state,\" Harris said on stage on Tuesday. \"In that job I walked underground tunnels between the United States and Mexico on that border with law enforcement officers. I went after transnational gangs, drug cartels and human traffickers that came into our country illegally. I prosecuted them in case after case, and I won. Donald Trump, on the other hand, has been talking a big game about securing our border, but he does not walk the walk. Or, as my friend Quavo would say, he does not walk it like he talks it.\"\n\nBiden -- with Harris' help -- won Georgia in 2020, but it will be a heavier lift four years later: As Rolling Stone has reported, Trump's allies' have transformed the state into a \"laboratory\" for strategies to contest the 2024 election, as one source close to the former president put it. Georgia Republicans have enacted a sweeping voter suppression law, empowered activists to file mass challenges to residents' voter registrations, and packed the state and county election boards with Trump devotees who both believe his lies about the 2020 election and who have shown an increasing willingness to refuse to certify election results.\n\nBy launching her campaign in Atlanta, the Harris campaign was sending a clear signal: They intend to compete everywhere, including in states that seemed, two weeks ago, to be slipping out of their grip.\n\nAccording to the campaign, more than 7,500 have signed up to volunteer in Georgia in the last week alone. In a call with reporters ahead of the launch, a Georgia state director for the Harris campaign reported that they've hired more than 170 Democratic staffers across 24 offices around the state -- the largest in-state operation of a Democratic presidential campaign, she said, ever. And when she touched down in Atlanta on Tuesday afternoon, it was the sixth time Vice President Harris has traveled to Georgia this year, and her 15th trip since taking office in 2020.\n\n\"I am very clear: the path to the White House runs right through this state,\" Harris said on Tuesday. \"You are helped us win in 2020 -- and we're going to do it again in 2024.\"", "source": {"uri": Beyonc\u00e9 let the world know she was down with the Harris campaign by allowing her to use her song \"Freedom\" as walkout music. choice to take on Donald Trump in the upcoming election.\n\nTaylor Swift is also rallying her Swifties to support VP Harris and ensure that Trump does not regain the White House.\n\nCardi B has shown happen alone.\n\nStill, Harris has made it clear after meeting with Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu that it's time for the war to end, and a two-state solution should be the end {"uri": "8251621824", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "02:39:36", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T02:39:36Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T02:38:25Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5803921818733215, "url": "https://dnyuz.com/2024/07/30/say-it-to-my-face-kamala-harris-challenges-donald-trump-to-debate-after-gop-nominee-goes-wobbly-over-next-matchup/", "title": "\"Say It To My Face!\" Kamala Harris Challenges Donald Trump To Debate After GOP Nominee Goes Wobbly Over Next Matchup", "body": "Joe Biden dropped out of the race on July 21, and this ain't your grandfather's election anymore.\n\nIf Donald Trump figured his usual petulance was going to put new Democratic ticket-topper Kamala Harris on the backfoot, the 78-year old ex-president might want to think again. In her first big rally as the nominee, the vice president called out the three-time Republican presidential candidate to keep his word about the ABC News-hosted debate set for September 10 that he had previously agreed to do against Biden.\n\n\"So the momentum in this race is shifting, and there are signs that Donald Trump is feeling it,\" the veep and presumptive Democratic nominee told an enthusiastic crowd of more than 10,000 just now in Atlanta as polls have Harris tied and even ahead of Trump a week into her White House bid. 'So last week, you may have seen, he pulled out of the debate in September he had previously agreed to,\" Harris added to laughs from the Georgia audience.\n\nMocking Trump as a chicken and the rhetoric from Trump and running mate Sen. J.D. Vance (R-OH) as \"just plain weird,\" Harris put her opponent on notice to the world with the political equivalent of a sidewinder.\n\nRELATED: White Dudes For Harris Online Rally Raises Millions In Donations But Then Sees X Account Suspended\n\n\"Donald, I do hope you'll reconsider to meet me on the debate stage,\" the VP said with maximum precision. \"As the saying goes, if you got something to say, say it to my face!\"\n\nWith Megan Thee Stallion, Stacey Abrams, Atlanta Mayor Andre Dickens and Georgia Sens. Jon Ossoff and Raphael Warnock in attendance, the crowd at the Georgia State Convocation Center went nuts.\n\nThat reaction to Harris' challenge was seen live on CNN and MSNBC, as well as the BBC. However, if you were watching the MAGA-friendly Fox News, you would have seen none of it. Over on the Rupert Murdoch-owned outlet, Laura Ingraham was slamming law enforcement for its investigation into the social media accounts of Thomas Crooks, the 21-year-old who tried to shoot Trump at a July 13 rally in Butler, PA.\n\nRELATED: Top Hollywood Donors Already Writing Checks, \"Excited & Motivated\" For Kamala Harris After Joe Biden's Exit\n\nThe Fox host also had more of her pre-recorded sit-down with Trump. An interview on Monday, Trump was shown telling Ingraham that he \"probably\" will face off against Harris in the fall, but he \"can also make a case for not doing it.\" When Ingraham tried to press Trump on getting in the ring with the vice president, the ex-Celebrity Apprentice host replied he didn't want to \"reward fake news\" like ABC or make them \"rich.\"\n\nRELATED: Michael Cieply: Will The Hollywood Glam Factor Hurt Kamala Harris?\n\nUp against a vert different candidate than the stumbling President Biden he took on back on June 27 on CNN, it is unsure if Trump will go face-to-face with Harris in a month. What is sure is that Trump will be in the Georgia State Convocation Center this weekend for a rally of his own. Stallion confirmed on her Instagram that she's heading down south to support Harris with a special performance. \"ATL HOTTIES SEE YOU TOMORROW,\" she wrote in a caption accompanying the news, reports Variety.com.
